• Mechanism of Action: Has a dual mechanism. It primarily decreases aqueous humor synthesis by stimulating α2 receptors on the ciliary body. It also increases uveoscleral outflow.
  • Clinical Use: A common agent for the long-term management of [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]].
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular side effects include allergic conjunctivitis, hyperemia (redness), and pruritus (itching). Systemic side effects are possible due to absorption and include dry mouth, sedation, and fatigue. Unlike apraclonidine, it does not cause mydriasis and can be used in angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Comparison: Similar to [[c1f67280|apraclonidine]] but is more selective for the α2 receptor and has a lower incidence of allergic reactions and tachyphylaxis, making it more suitable for long-term use.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that α2 agonists like brimonidine and clonidine act as sympatholytics, reducing sympathetic outflow. In the eye, this leads to decreased aqueous humor production.
content.takeAway: Brimonidine is an effective glaucoma medication that lowers intraocular pressure through a dual mechanism of decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing its outflow, all mediated by its selective α2-adrenergic agonism.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brimonidine] --> B(Stimulates α2 Receptors); B --> C(↓ Aqueous Humor Synthesis); B --> D(↑ Uveoscleral Outflow); C & D --> E(↓ Intraocular Pressure);

content.definition: Broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) that are effective against a wide variety of seizure types, including both focal and generalized seizures (e.g., tonic-clonic, absence, myoclonic).
content.atAGlance:
• Key Agents: The main broad-spectrum agents are [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]], [[08d19a8f|Lamotrigine]], [[2341f9c0|Levetiracetam]], and [[e1f5066c|Topiramate]].
  • Clinical Use: They are the drugs of choice when the seizure type is unclear or when a patient has multiple seizure types (e.g., Lennox-Gastaut syndrome).
  • Valproic Acid: Very broad spectrum, effective for almost all seizure types. Mechanism involves Na+ channel blockade, T-type Ca2+ channel blockade, and increasing GABA levels. Highly teratogenic (neural tube defects).
  • Lamotrigine: Broad spectrum, but must be titrated slowly to reduce the risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).
  • Levetiracetam: Very commonly used due to its favorable side effect profile and broad efficacy. Unique mechanism involving synaptic vesicle protein 2A (SV2A).
  • USMLE Tip: If a question asks for the best initial treatment for a patient with generalized tonic-clonic seizures, a broad-spectrum agent like valproic acid or levetiracetam is a strong choice. Valproic acid is also a first-line option for myoclonic seizures.
content.takeAway: Broad-spectrum anticonvulsants are the versatile workhorses of epilepsy treatment, effective against both focal and generalized seizures, making them ideal for initial empirical therapy or for patients with complex epilepsy syndromes.

content.definition: Broca's aphasia, also known as expressive aphasia, is a language disorder characterized by difficulty in producing fluent, grammatical speech, while comprehension remains relatively intact. It is caused by a lesion in [[a3bbace2|Broca's area]].
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Location: Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
  • Vascular Supply: Supplied by the superior division of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Clinical Presentation: Speech is nonfluent, telegraphic, and effortful. Patients use short phrases and omit functional words (e.g., "Walk dog"). Repetition is impaired.
  • Comprehension: Auditory and reading comprehension are relatively preserved, although complex grammar may be difficult.
  • Patient Awareness: Patients are typically aware of their deficits and become very frustrated by their inability to communicate effectively.
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: Broca's is Broken Boca (mouth). Look for a patient with a right hemiparesis (especially face and arm) who can follow commands but struggles to speak in complete sentences.
content.takeAway: Broca's aphasia is a disorder of language production, not comprehension, resulting from damage to the brain's motor-speech planning center. The resulting speech is broken and effortful, leaving the patient frustratingly aware of their inability to express their intact thoughts.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion in Broca's Area] --> B(Impaired Speech Production); B --> C(Nonfluent, Telegraphic Speech); A --Spares--> D(Wernicke's Area); D --> E(Intact Comprehension);

content.definition: Broca's area is a region in the frontal lobe of the dominant hemisphere (usually the left) of the brain with functions linked to speech production.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (Brodmann areas 44 and 45).
  • Function: Responsible for the motor planning and execution of speech. It coordinates the movements of the larynx, tongue, and lips necessary for articulation.
  • Vascular Supply: Supplied by the superior division of the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Lesion Effect: Damage to this area results in [[7f6ed344|Broca's aphasia]] (expressive aphasia), characterized by nonfluent, agrammatical speech with intact comprehension.
  • Connection: It is connected to [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]] (language comprehension) by a bundle of nerve fibers called the arcuate fasciculus.
  • USMLE Tip: A stroke affecting the left MCA is the most common cause of damage to Broca's area. Because of its proximity to the primary motor cortex, [[7f6ed344|Broca's aphasia]] is often accompanied by contralateral weakness of the face and arm.
content.takeAway: Broca's area is the brain's 'speech production factory,' translating thoughts and concepts from Wernicke's area into the precise motor commands needed for fluent articulation; a lesion here breaks the production line, resulting in expressive aphasia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Wernicke's Area - Comprehension] --Arcuate Fasciculus--> B(Broca's Area); B --Motor Plan--> C(Primary Motor Cortex); C --> D(Speech Articulation);

content.definition: Bromocriptine is an ergot derivative that acts as a dopamine D2 receptor agonist. It is used to treat conditions associated with hyperprolactinemia and [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Stimulates dopamine D2 receptors in the CNS and periphery.
  • Clinical Use (Endocrinology): Treats hyperprolactinemia and prolactinomas by stimulating D2 receptors on lactotrophs in the anterior pituitary, which inhibits prolactin secretion. Also used for acromegaly as it can suppress GH secretion.
  • Clinical Use (Neurology): Used as an adjunctive therapy in [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] to stimulate dopamine receptors in the striatum. It is an ergot derivative and is less commonly used now than non-ergot agonists (e.g., pramipexole, ropinirole) due to its side effect profile.
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, vomiting, postural hypotension, and headache. As an ergot derivative, it can cause pulmonary fibrosis and vasospasm.
  • USMLE Tip: Bromocriptine is a classic treatment for prolactinomas. Remember that dopamine tonically inhibits prolactin release, so a dopamine agonist will lower prolactin levels.
content.takeAway: Bromocriptine is a dopamine D2 agonist that leverages dopamine's inhibitory control over prolactin to treat hyperprolactinemia and supplements dopamine signaling in the basal ganglia to treat Parkinson disease, though its use is limited by its ergot-related side effects.

content.definition: Brown-Séquard syndrome is a rare neurological condition caused by hemisection of the spinal cord, resulting in a characteristic pattern of ipsilateral motor and proprioceptive loss, and contralateral pain and temperature sensory loss below the level of the lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Typically caused by trauma, such as a penetrating injury (e.g., stab wound) or a tumor compressing one half of the spinal cord.
  • Ipsilateral Deficits (at and below lesion):
    - Motor: Ipsilateral spastic paralysis below the lesion (corticospinal tract damage).
    - Sensation: Ipsilateral loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch below the lesion ([[e7f5cbbe|dorsal column]] damage).
  • Contralateral Deficits (below lesion):
    - Sensation: Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation, typically beginning 1-2 segments below the lesion (spinothalamic tract damage, as fibers decussate in the spinal cord).
  • Deficits at the Level of the Lesion:
    - Ipsilateral flaccid paralysis (LMN damage at that level).
    - Ipsilateral complete loss of all sensation.
  • USMLE Tip: This syndrome is a classic test of spinal cord tract anatomy. The key is remembering which tracts cross in the medulla (dorsal columns, corticospinal) versus the spinal cord (spinothalamic). If the lesion is above T1, an ipsilateral [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]] may also be present.
content.takeAway: Brown-Séquard syndrome is the ultimate clinical demonstration of spinal cord neuroanatomy, creating a striking dissociation of deficits where one side of the body loses motor function and proprioception, while the other side loses the ability to feel pain and temperature, all due to a unilateral cord lesion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Spinal Cord Hemisection at T10]; A --> B(Ipsilateral (Right) Deficits); B --> C(Loss of Motor, Proprioception, Vibration below T10); B --> D(Flaccid paralysis at T10); A --> E(Contralateral (Left) Deficits); E --> F(Loss of Pain & Temperature below T10);

content.definition: Bulbar palsy refers to a set of clinical signs resulting from damage to the lower motor neurons (LMNs) of the cranial nerves originating in the brainstem (medulla oblongata, or 'bulb'). Specifically, it involves cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), XI (accessory), and XII (hypoglossal).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by LMN lesions of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII.
  • Clinical Presentation: Characterized by flaccid weakness of the muscles of the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. This leads to dysarthria (slurred speech), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), drooling, and a hoarse or nasal voice.
  • Physical Exam Findings: On examination, there is tongue wasting and fasciculations (LMN signs), a diminished or absent gag reflex, and the palate may not elevate symmetrically.
  • Causes: Can be seen in [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]], Guillain-Barré syndrome, myasthenia gravis, and brainstem strokes or tumors.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from pseudobulbar palsy, which is caused by upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions. Pseudobulbar palsy presents with a spastic dysarthria, an exaggerated gag reflex, and emotional lability (pseudobulbar affect), without tongue atrophy or fasciculations.
content.takeAway: Bulbar palsy is a manifestation of lower motor neuron damage to the lower cranial nerves, resulting in a flaccid paralysis of the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal muscles, which must be distinguished from the spastic paralysis of the same muscles seen in the upper motor neuron condition, pseudobulbar palsy.

content.definition: Bupivacaine is a long-acting, amide-type local anesthetic commonly used for regional anesthesia, such as epidurals for labor and spinal anesthesia for surgical procedures.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels in nerve membranes, preventing the generation and conduction of nerve impulses.
  • Class: Amide local anesthetic (has two 'i's in its name).
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a long duration of action, making it suitable for prolonged procedures and postoperative pain control.
  • Clinical Use: Widely used for epidural analgesia, spinal anesthesia, and peripheral nerve blocks.
  • Adverse Effect: The most notable adverse effect is severe cardiotoxicity. It is more cardiotoxic than other local anesthetics. Accidental intravascular injection can lead to severe ventricular arrhythmias and cardiovascular collapse that is difficult to resuscitate.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember bupivacaine for its long duration of action and its significant risk of cardiotoxicity. This risk is a major consideration in its clinical use and dosing.
content.takeAway: Bupivacaine is a potent, long-acting amide anesthetic favored for epidurals and nerve blocks, but its use is shadowed by a significant risk of severe cardiotoxicity if accidentally injected systemically.

content.definition: Buprenorphine is a semi-synthetic opioid that acts as a partial agonist at the μ-opioid receptor and an antagonist at the κ-opioid receptor. It is used for both pain management and the treatment of opioid use disorder.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: As a partial μ-opioid agonist, it binds with high affinity but has lower intrinsic activity than full agonists like morphine. This creates a 'ceiling effect' on respiratory depression, making it safer in overdose than full agonists.
  • Clinical Use (Opioid Use Disorder): Used for opioid detoxification and maintenance therapy. It can precipitate withdrawal if given to a patient who is currently using full opioids due to its high affinity and lower intrinsic activity. Often co-formulated with naloxone (Suboxone) to deter IV abuse.
  • Clinical Use (Pain): Effective for moderate to severe chronic pain, available in various formulations including transdermal patches.
  • Reversal: Its effects are not easily reversed by naloxone due to its high affinity for the μ-receptor, requiring higher doses of the antagonist.
  • USMLE Tip: The key concept for buprenorphine is 'partial agonist.' This explains its ceiling effect on respiratory depression and its ability to precipitate withdrawal in an opioid-dependent individual.
content.takeAway: Buprenorphine is a unique opioid that acts as a partial agonist, providing analgesia and mitigating withdrawal symptoms with a lower risk of respiratory depression, but its high receptor affinity means it can displace full agonists and precipitate withdrawal if not initiated carefully.

content.definition: Butorphanol is a synthetic opioid analgesic that functions as a mixed agonist-antagonist. It is primarily used for the management of moderate to severe pain.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a κ-opioid receptor agonist and a μ-opioid receptor partial agonist or weak antagonist.
  • Analgesic Effect: The κ-agonist activity provides strong analgesia.
  • Ceiling Effect: Like other mixed agonist-antagonists, it exhibits a ceiling effect for respiratory depression, making it potentially safer in overdose compared to full μ-agonists.
  • Clinical Use: Used for moderate to severe pain, particularly in labor (less neonatal respiratory depression) and for postoperative pain. Also available as a nasal spray for [[c8833bae|migraines]].
  • Adverse Effects: Can cause sedation, nausea, and psychotomimetic effects (e.g., hallucinations, dysphoria) due to κ-receptor agonism. It can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in patients physically dependent on full μ-opioid agonists.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that mixed agonist-antagonists like butorphanol and nalbuphine can precipitate withdrawal in opioid-dependent patients. Their primary analgesic effect comes from κ-agonism.
content.takeAway: Butorphanol is a mixed-action opioid that provides potent analgesia through κ-receptor agonism while having a limited effect on μ-receptors, which gives it a better safety profile regarding respiratory depression but also the potential to induce withdrawal in opioid-dependent individuals.

content.definition: Cabergoline is a long-acting ergot derivative that is a potent dopamine D2 receptor agonist. It is the first-line treatment for hyperprolactinemia and prolactin-secreting [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenomas]] (prolactinomas).
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Stimulates D2 receptors on lactotrophs in the [[76ba7f2e|anterior pituitary]], mimicking the natural inhibitory effect of dopamine on prolactin secretion. This leads to a decrease in serum prolactin levels and can cause shrinkage of prolactinomas.
  • Clinical Use: First-line treatment for prolactinomas and hyperprolactinemia. Also used in [[acromegaly]] (can suppress GH secretion) and [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a long half-life, allowing for once or twice weekly dosing, which improves patient compliance compared to [[d24a5ff0|bromocriptine]].
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, headache, postural hypotension. Less nausea than bromocriptine. High doses have been associated with valvular heart disease, but this is rare at the doses used for hyperprolactinemia.
  • USMLE Tip: Cabergoline is preferred over [[d24a5ff0|bromocriptine]] for treating prolactinomas due to its higher efficacy, better side-effect profile, and more convenient dosing schedule.
content.takeAway: Cabergoline is the superior dopamine agonist for treating hyperprolactinemia, effectively suppressing prolactin secretion and shrinking pituitary tumors by powerfully stimulating D2 receptors, with the clinical advantage of a long half-life and better tolerability.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cabergoline] --> B(Stimulates D2 Receptors on Lactotrophs); B --> C(↓ Prolactin Secretion); C --> D(↓ Serum Prolactin & Tumor Shrinkage);

content.definition: Café-au-lait spots are well-demarcated, hyperpigmented macules or patches on the skin, with a color resembling 'coffee with milk.' While a few small spots can be normal, the presence of multiple, large spots is a hallmark of several genetic syndromes, most notably Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: Flat, pigmented birthmarks with a light brown color and distinct borders.
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1): The presence of six or more café-au-lait spots greater than 5 mm in diameter in prepubertal individuals (or >15 mm in postpubertal individuals) is a key diagnostic criterion for NF-1. The spots in NF-1 typically have smooth borders ('coast of California').
  • McCune-Albright Syndrome: Characterized by a triad of fibrous dysplasia of bone, endocrine abnormalities (like precocious puberty), and large, unilateral café-au-lait spots with irregular, jagged borders ('coast of Maine').
  • Other Associations: Can also be seen in tuberous sclerosis, Fanconi anemia, and other syndromes, but are most strongly associated with NF-1.
  • USMLE Tip: Multiple café-au-lait spots in a child should prompt a thorough evaluation for other signs of Neurofibromatosis Type 1, such as axillary freckling, Lisch nodules, and neurofibromas.
content.takeAway: While often benign, multiple café-au-lait spots are a crucial dermatological clue to underlying systemic genetic disorders, with the number and border characteristics (smooth in NF-1, irregular in McCune-Albright) helping to narrow the differential diagnosis.

content.definition: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP) is a 37-amino acid neuropeptide that is widely distributed in the central and peripheral nervous systems. It is a potent vasodilator and is critically involved in pain transmission, particularly in the pathophysiology of [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Acts as a potent arterial vasodilator and a neurotransmitter/neuromodulator in pain pathways.
  • Role in Migraine: During a migraine attack, CGRP is released from trigeminal nerve endings. This release causes vasodilation of cranial blood vessels and promotes neurogenic inflammation, contributing to the pain of a migraine.
  • Therapeutic Target: CGRP and its receptor have become major targets for migraine therapy.
  • Drug Classes Targeting CGRP:
    1. [[4770b8a2|Anti-CGRP Monoclonal Antibodies]] (e.g., erenumab, galcanezumab): Used for migraine prophylaxis.
    2. Gepants (e.g., ubrogepant, rimegepant): Small molecule CGRP receptor antagonists used for acute treatment of migraines.
  • USMLE Tip: The central role of CGRP in migraine pathophysiology is a high-yield concept. Understand that blocking the CGRP pathway, either with monoclonal antibodies for prevention or gepants for acute attacks, is a modern, targeted approach to migraine treatment.
content.takeAway: Calcitonin Gene-Related Peptide (CGRP) is a key player in the generation of migraine pain, acting as both a powerful vasodilator and a pain-signaling molecule in the trigeminal system, making its blockade a highly effective strategy for migraine therapy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Trigeminal Nerve Activation] --> B(Release of CGRP); B --> C(Vasodilation & Neurogenic Inflammation); C --> D(Migraine Pain);

content.definition: Capsaicin is the active component of chili peppers and is used topically as an analgesic for neuropathic and musculoskeletal pain. It works by interacting with the transient receptor potential vanilloid 1 (TRPV1) receptor on nociceptive nerve fibers.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Initially, capsaicin activates TRPV1 receptors (also known as capsaicin receptors), causing an influx of calcium and the release of substance P, which leads to a burning sensation. With repeated application, it causes desensitization of the nerve fibers and depletion of substance P, resulting in an analgesic effect.
  • Clinical Use: Used topically for neuropathic pain (e.g., postherpetic neuralgia, diabetic neuropathy) and musculoskeletal pain (e.g., osteoarthritis).
  • Administration: Available as a low-concentration over-the-counter cream or a high-concentration prescription patch.
  • Adverse Effects: The most common side effect is a localized burning, stinging, or erythema at the application site, which typically diminishes with continued use.
  • USMLE Tip: The key mechanism to remember is the initial activation followed by desensitization and depletion of substance P from sensory nerve endings.
content.takeAway: Capsaicin paradoxically relieves pain by first causing it; its initial stimulation of pain receptors leads to their eventual desensitization and the depletion of substance P, effectively silencing the pain signals from the affected area.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Topical Capsaicin] --> B(Activates TRPV1 Receptors); B --> C(Initial Release of Substance P); C --> D(Burning Sensation); B --Repeated Application--> E(Desensitization & Depletion of Substance P); E --> F(Analgesia);

content.definition: Caput succedaneum is a benign, edematous swelling of the soft tissues of a newborn's scalp that is present at birth. It is caused by pressure on the infant's head from the cervix or vaginal wall during a prolonged or difficult delivery.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: The edema is located in the subcutaneous tissue, superficial to the periosteum of the skull.
  • Clinical Presentation: A soft, puffy, and sometimes ecchymotic swelling on the scalp. A key feature is that it crosses suture lines.
  • Timing: Present at birth and typically resolves spontaneously within a few days.
  • Differentiation: It must be distinguished from a [[a1721d6f|cephalohematoma]].
    - Caput Succedaneum: Soft, pits on pressure, crosses suture lines, resolves quickly.
    - Cephalohematoma: Firm, does not cross suture lines (subperiosteal), resolves over weeks to months, may calcify.
  • USMLE Tip: The ability to cross suture lines is the most important feature for distinguishing caput succedaneum from a cephalohematoma on an exam.
content.takeAway: Caput succedaneum is a benign and self-resolving scalp edema in newborns resulting from birth trauma, easily identified by its soft consistency and its ability to cross cranial suture lines, distinguishing it from the more localized and potentially complicated cephalohematoma.

content.definition: Carbachol is a cholinomimetic agent that acts as a non-selective agonist at both muscarinic and nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It is primarily used in ophthalmology to treat glaucoma.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: As a direct cholinergic agonist, it mimics the effects of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]]. In the eye, it stimulates muscarinic (M3) receptors on the ciliary muscle and the sphincter pupillae muscle.
  • Ocular Effects:
    1. Miosis: Contraction of the sphincter pupillae muscle causes pupillary constriction.
    2. ↓ IOP: Contraction of the ciliary muscle increases the outflow of aqueous humor through the trabecular meshwork, lowering intraocular pressure.
  • Clinical Use: Used topically to treat [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]] and to produce miosis during ophthalmic surgery. It is less commonly used than pilocarpine.
  • Resistance to AChE: Carbachol is resistant to hydrolysis by acetylcholinesterase, giving it a longer duration of action than acetylcholine.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember carbachol as a direct-acting cholinomimetic that lowers IOP by increasing trabecular outflow, a mechanism shared with pilocarpine.
content.takeAway: Carbachol is a potent, long-acting acetylcholine mimic that effectively lowers intraocular pressure in glaucoma by contracting the ciliary muscle to open up the trabecular meshwork drainage channels.

content.definition: Carbamazepine is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant drug that works by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels. It is also used as a mood stabilizer and for the treatment of neuropathic pain.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels in their inactivated state, which prolongs the refractory period of the neuron and prevents repetitive firing.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Seizures: First-line treatment for focal seizures (both simple and complex) and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
    - Neuropathic Pain: First-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia.
    - Bipolar Disorder: Used as a mood stabilizer.
  • Adverse Effects: Diplopia, ataxia, SIADH (hyponatremia), and skin rashes. Two serious, rare side effects are agranulocytosis and aplastic anemia, requiring monitoring of CBC. It is also a potent inducer of cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to many drug interactions.
  • Teratogenicity: Associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in pregnancy.
  • USMLE Tip: Carbamazepine is the drug of choice for trigeminal neuralgia. Remember its major hematologic side effects (agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia) and its induction of the P450 system.
content.takeAway: Carbamazepine is a cornerstone therapy for focal seizures and trigeminal neuralgia, acting by stabilizing inactivated sodium channels, but its use requires careful monitoring due to the risk of severe hematologic toxicity and its potent induction of hepatic enzymes.

content.definition: Carbidopa/Levodopa (trade name Sinemet) is the most effective and widely used combination drug for the symptomatic treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]]. Levodopa is a metabolic precursor to dopamine, while carbidopa is a peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    - Levodopa (L-DOPA): Can cross the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]] (unlike dopamine) and is converted to [[90adc821|dopamine]] in the CNS by DOPA decarboxylase, replenishing the depleted dopamine stores in the striatum.
    - Carbidopa: Inhibits peripheral DOPA decarboxylase. This prevents the conversion of L-DOPA to dopamine in the periphery, which increases the bioavailability of L-DOPA in the brain and reduces peripheral side effects (like nausea and arrhythmias).
  • Clinical Use: The cornerstone of treatment for [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], particularly effective for bradykinesia and rigidity.
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, hallucinations, postural hypotension. Long-term use is associated with motor fluctuations ('on-off' phenomenon) and dyskinesias (involuntary movements).
  • USMLE Tip: The rationale for the combination is key: Carbidopa acts as a 'bodyguard' for Levodopa, ensuring more of it reaches the brain where it's needed, while minimizing side effects elsewhere in the body.
content.takeAway: The Carbidopa/Levodopa combination is a brilliant pharmacological strategy that overcomes the blood-brain barrier by using a precursor (Levodopa) and then protecting that precursor from peripheral breakdown (with Carbidopa) to effectively deliver dopamine to the deficient basal ganglia in Parkinson's disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Levodopa] --Peripheral DOPA Decarboxylase--> B(Dopamine - Periphery); C[Carbidopa] --x B; A --> D(Crosses BBB); D --> E[L-DOPA in CNS]; E --Central DOPA Decarboxylase--> F(Dopamine - CNS); F --> G(Treats Parkinson's Symptoms);

content.definition: A Carotid-Cavernous Fistula (CCF) is an abnormal communication between the internal carotid artery and the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]]. This creates a high-flow, high-pressure arteriovenous shunt within the sinus, leading to a characteristic set of signs and symptoms.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Can be traumatic (e.g., from a basal skull fracture) or spontaneous (e.g., from a ruptured intracavernous carotid aneurysm).
  • Pathophysiology: Arterial blood from the internal carotid artery flows directly into the low-pressure [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]]. This increases pressure in the sinus and reverses blood flow in the veins that drain into it, particularly the superior ophthalmic vein.
  • Clinical Triad: The classic triad is pulsatile exophthalmos (protruding, pulsating eye), ocular bruit (a whooshing sound heard over the eye), and chemosis (conjunctival edema and redness).
  • Other Symptoms: Patients also develop ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles) due to dysfunction of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI, which all traverse the cavernous sinus. There may also be sensory loss in the V1 and V2 distribution.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of a pulsating eye and an audible bruit over the eye after head trauma is pathognomonic for a carotid-cavernous fistula.
content.takeAway: A Carotid-Cavernous Fistula creates a high-pressure vascular storm within the cavernous sinus, engorging the orbital veins and compressing the cranial nerves that pass through it, resulting in the dramatic clinical picture of a pulsating, red, and paralyzed eye.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Internal Carotid Artery] --Fistula--> B(Cavernous Sinus); B --> C(↑ Pressure in Sinus); C --> D(Reversal of flow in Superior Ophthalmic Vein); D --> E(Pulsatile Exophthalmos, Chemosis, Bruit); C --> F(Compression of CN III, IV, V1, V2, VI); F --> G(Ophthalmoplegia, Sensory Loss);

content.definition: Carteolol is a non-selective β-adrenergic antagonist (beta-blocker) used as a topical eye drop to reduce intraocular pressure (IOP) in the treatment of [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]] and ocular hypertension.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks both β1 and β2 adrenergic receptors on the ciliary epithelium. This leads to a decrease in aqueous humor production, thereby lowering IOP.
  • Class: Non-selective beta-blocker, similar to [[ae28be6c|timolol]].
  • Clinical Use: A first-line agent for [[5ea7b741|open-angle glaucoma]].
  • Adverse Effects: Ocular side effects include stinging and burning. Systemic absorption can occur, potentially causing bradycardia, hypotension, fatigue, and bronchoconstriction.
  • Contraindications: Should be used with caution in patients with asthma, COPD, bradycardia, or heart block due to its non-selective β-blockade.
  • USMLE Tip: Like all non-selective beta-blockers used for glaucoma, carteolol's main mechanism is decreasing aqueous humor production. Be aware of the potential for systemic side effects, especially bronchospasm in patients with reactive airway disease.
content.takeAway: Carteolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that effectively treats glaucoma by turning down the 'faucet' of aqueous humor production in the ciliary body, but its systemic absorption carries the risk of β-blockade side effects throughout the body.

content.definition: A cataract is a painless, progressive opacification or clouding of the normally clear lens of the eye, which leads to a decrease in vision. It is the leading cause of blindness worldwide.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Involves the denaturation and aggregation of lens proteins (crystallins), leading to loss of transparency and light scattering.
  • Risk Factors: Increased age is the most common risk factor. Others include smoking, excessive alcohol use, excessive sunlight (UV) exposure, prolonged glucocorticoid use, trauma, and infection.
  • Systemic Disease Associations: Diabetes mellitus (due to sorbitol accumulation via aldose reductase), classic galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency, and myotonic dystrophy.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients report painless, progressive blurring of vision, glare (especially at night with oncoming headlights), and often a myopic shift (nearsightedness). On exam, there is loss of the red reflex and the lens appears opaque.
  • Treatment: The definitive treatment is surgical removal of the opacified lens and replacement with an artificial intraocular lens.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the association with diabetes and galactosemia, where excess sugars are converted to osmotically active polyols (sorbitol, galactitol) in the lens, causing hydropic swelling and opacification.
content.takeAway: Cataracts represent a clouding of the eye's lens due to protein aggregation, most commonly as a part of aging, which scatters light and causes progressive, painless vision loss that can only be definitively treated by surgical lens replacement.

content.definition: The Cauda Equina (Latin for "horse's tail") is the bundle of spinal nerves and spinal nerve rootlets, consisting of the second through fifth lumbar nerve pairs, the first through fifth sacral nerve pairs, and the coccygeal nerve, all of which arise from the lumbar enlargement and the conus medullaris of the spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomy: Comprises the nerve roots from L2 to Co1 that descend through the lumbar cistern (subarachnoid space) below the termination of the spinal cord proper (conus medullaris, typically at L1-L2).
  • Function: These nerve roots provide motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities, perineum, and pelvic organs (including the bladder and anal sphincters).
  • Clinical Significance: Compression of these nerve roots leads to [[2904b5c8|Cauda Equina Syndrome]], a neurosurgical emergency.
  • Lumbar Puncture: The cauda equina floats in the cerebrospinal fluid of the lumbar cistern, which is the target for a lumbar puncture. The needle is typically inserted at the L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspace to avoid injuring the spinal cord.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the spinal cord ends at L1-L2 in adults. The collection of nerve roots continuing down the vertebral canal below this level is the cauda equina.
content.takeAway: The Cauda Equina is the collection of descending lumbar and sacral nerve roots that resemble a horse's tail, filling the subarachnoid space below the end of the spinal cord; its compression results in the surgical emergency known as cauda equina syndrome.

content.definition: Cauda Equina Syndrome is a neurosurgical emergency caused by severe compression of the [[1c4d7e8f|cauda equina]], the bundle of nerve roots at the lower end of the spinal canal. This compression leads to a constellation of debilitating symptoms requiring urgent surgical decompression.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by a massive midline lumbar disc herniation. Other causes include spinal stenosis, tumors, trauma, and epidural abscess or hematoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Characterized by a combination of symptoms including severe low back pain, radicular pain in one or both legs, and saddle anesthesia (loss of sensation in the perineum, buttocks, and inner thighs).
  • Red Flag Symptoms: The most critical signs are bowel and/or bladder dysfunction (e.g., urinary retention or incontinence) and loss of the [[ce2052d6|anal wink reflex]].
  • Motor/Sensory Deficits: Patients typically have asymmetric, flaccid paralysis or weakness in the lower extremities (LMN signs) and sensory loss.
  • Treatment: Urgent surgical decompression is required to relieve the pressure on the nerve roots and prevent permanent paralysis and incontinence.
  • USMLE Tip: The combination of low back pain, saddle anesthesia, and new-onset urinary retention is the classic triad for Cauda Equina Syndrome and warrants immediate surgical consultation.
content.takeAway: Cauda Equina Syndrome is a critical condition where compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots leads to a devastating loss of lower extremity and pelvic floor function; its hallmark 'red flag' symptoms of saddle anesthesia and bladder/bowel dysfunction signal the need for immediate surgical intervention to prevent permanent disability.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Massive Lumbar Disc Herniation] --Compresses--> B(Cauda Equina); B --> C(Saddle Anesthesia); B --> D(Bowel/Bladder Dysfunction); B --> E(Lower Extremity Weakness);

content.definition: The Caudate Nucleus is a C-shaped nucleus that is a key component of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]]. Together with the putamen, it forms the striatum, which is the main input station for the basal ganglia circuits involved in motor control and cognitive functions.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomy: A large C-shaped structure with a head, body, and tail that follows the curve of the lateral ventricle.
  • Function: The caudate is primarily involved in the cognitive aspects of movement, including motor planning and procedural learning. It also plays a role in reward and motivation.
  • Striatum: The caudate and putamen are collectively known as the striatum.
  • Pathology: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus is the hallmark pathological finding in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].
  • Imaging Finding: The degeneration of the caudate head in Huntington disease leads to the characteristic appearance of enlarged lateral ventricles on brain imaging (ex vacuo ventriculomegaly).
  • USMLE Tip: The association between caudate atrophy and [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]] is extremely high-yield. A brain scan showing 'boxcar' ventricles due to a shrunken caudate in a patient with chorea is classic for Huntington's.
content.takeAway: The Caudate Nucleus is a critical part of the basal ganglia's cognitive loop, and its profound atrophy in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]] is directly responsible for both the characteristic motor (chorea) and cognitive (dementia) decline seen in the disorder.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Caudate Nucleus] --Atrophy in Huntington's Disease--> B(Enlarged Lateral Ventricles); A --Part of Striatum--> C(Receives Cortical Input); C --> D(Modulates Motor & Cognitive Function);

content.definition: The Cavernous Sinus is a paired dural venous sinus located on either side of the sella turcica of the sphenoid bone. It is a unique venous structure because several critical cranial nerves and the internal carotid artery pass directly through it.
content.atAGlance:
• Contents: Mnemonic O TOM CAT (from superior to inferior on lateral wall, then medially):
    - Oculomotor n. (CN III)
    - Trochlear n. (CN IV)
    - Ophthalmic n. (CN V1)
    - Maxillary n. (CN V2)
    - Carotid artery (internal)
    - Abducens n. (CN VI)
    - T (ignore)
  • Location of CN VI: The [[dd11dde6|abducens nerve (CN VI)]] is the only nerve that runs freely within the sinus, next to the internal carotid artery, making it particularly vulnerable to injury.
  • Drainage: Receives venous blood from the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins and drains into the superior and inferior petrosal sinuses, which then drain to the internal jugular vein.
  • Clinical Syndromes:
    - [[9a089fd7|Cavernous Sinus Syndrome]]: A mass effect (e.g., tumor, aneurysm) causing ophthalmoplegia, decreased corneal sensation, and Horner syndrome.
    - [[a830692a|Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis]]: A blood clot in the sinus, often from a spreading facial or sinus infection, causing similar symptoms plus signs of infection and venous congestion (proptosis, chemosis).
  • USMLE Tip: Any patient presenting with multiple cranial nerve palsies involving eye movement (CN III, IV, VI) should raise suspicion for a lesion in the cavernous sinus.
content.takeAway: The Cavernous Sinus is a critical neurovascular crossroads where cranial nerves controlling eye movement and facial sensation travel alongside the internal carotid artery, making it a 'danger zone' where pathology can cause a complex ophthalmoplegia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cavernous Sinus]; A --> B(CN III); A --> C(CN IV); A --> D(CN V1/V2); A --> E(CN VI); A --> F(Internal Carotid Artery);

content.definition: Cavernous Sinus Syndrome is a clinical constellation of signs and symptoms resulting from any pathological process that affects the contents of the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]], leading to multiple cranial nerve palsies and potentially venous congestion of the orbit.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by mass effect from tumors (e.g., [[5f3188bd|pituitary adenoma]]), aneurysms of the internal carotid artery, [[a830692a|cavernous sinus thrombosis]], or inflammation (e.g., Tolosa-Hunt syndrome).
  • Clinical Presentation: A combination of:
    - Ophthalmoplegia: Paralysis of eye movements due to involvement of CN III, IV, and VI.
    - Sensory Loss: Decreased sensation in the forehead and cheek due to involvement of CN V1 and V2.
    - Pupillary Changes: Can have a dilated pupil (CN III compression) or a constricted pupil (Horner syndrome from sympathetic plexus damage).
  • Venous Congestion: If caused by thrombosis or a fistula, may see proptosis (bulging eye) and chemosis (conjunctival swelling).
  • USMLE Tip: The key to recognizing this syndrome is the involvement of multiple cranial nerves that all pass through one specific anatomical location: the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]]. The [[dd11dde6|abducens nerve (CN VI)]] is often the first nerve affected due to its medial location within the sinus.
content.takeAway: Cavernous Sinus Syndrome is the clinical manifestation of a 'mass lesion' within the cavernous sinus, presenting as a complex ophthalmoplegia with facial sensory loss, a direct result of compressing the tightly packed cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI.

content.definition: Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot within the [[c260efc8|cavernous sinus]], a rare but life-threatening condition that is most often caused by a contiguous spread of infection from the face, sinuses, or teeth.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly a septic thrombosis resulting from infection. The most common pathogen is Staphylococcus aureus. Infection can spread from the 'danger triangle' of the face, sphenoid or ethmoid sinuses, or dental abscesses via the valveless facial venous system.
  • Pathophysiology: The thrombus obstructs venous drainage and causes inflammation, leading to increased pressure within the sinus and compression of its contents.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients present with severe headache, high fever, and signs of [[9a089fd7|cavernous sinus syndrome]]: ophthalmoplegia (CN III, IV, VI palsy), periorbital edema, proptosis, and chemosis. The [[dd11dde6|abducens nerve (CN VI)]] is often affected first.
  • Diagnosis: MRI with magnetic resonance venography (MRV) is the imaging modality of choice.
  • Treatment: Requires prompt initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and consideration of anticoagulation.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a recent facial furuncle or sinusitis who develops a severe headache, fever, and unilateral eye swelling with impaired eye movements is the classic presentation for cavernous sinus thrombosis.
content.takeAway: Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis is a septic clot in the brain's central venous drainage system, typically seeded by a facial infection, which rapidly evolves into a neuro-ophthalmologic emergency with high fever, headache, and paralysis of eye movements.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Facial/Sinus Infection] --Staph. aureus--> B(Spread via Valveless Veins); B --> C(Cavernous Sinus); C --> D(Thrombosis & Inflammation); D --> E(Cavernous Sinus Syndrome);

content.definition: Central Post-Stroke Pain Syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome or Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, is a chronic neuropathic pain condition that develops after a [[c5da3c57|stroke]], most classically one affecting the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by a stroke (usually ischemic) affecting the somatosensory pathways, particularly the ventroposterolateral (VPL) nucleus of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]].
  • Timeline: Pain does not occur immediately after the stroke. There is typically an initial loss of sensation (numbness) in the affected area, with the pain developing weeks to months later.
  • Clinical Presentation: Characterized by severe, persistent, and often debilitating pain on the side of the body contralateral to the stroke. The pain is often described as burning, aching, or lancinating.
  • Key Feature: Allodynia (pain provoked by a normally non-painful stimulus, like light touch) and hyperalgesia (exaggerated pain response to a painful stimulus) are hallmarks of the condition.
  • Treatment: Very difficult to treat. Options include antidepressants (TCAs like [[c6814506|amitriptyline]]), anticonvulsants (e.g., gabapentin, pregabalin), and in refractory cases, deep brain stimulation.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a history of a stroke who later develops severe, burning pain and allodynia on the previously numb side of their body is the classic presentation.
content.takeAway: Central Post-Stroke Pain Syndrome is a cruel paradox of sensory processing, where a thalamic stroke that initially causes numbness later gives rise to intractable neuropathic pain and allodynia due to maladaptive plasticity in the damaged central sensory pathways.

content.definition: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) is an ophthalmologic emergency characterized by the sudden, painless, and profound loss of monocular vision due to obstruction of the central retinal artery, which supplies the inner retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Most commonly caused by a thromboembolism. The most frequent source is an atherosclerotic plaque in the ipsilateral carotid artery. Other sources include cardiogenic emboli (e.g., from atrial fibrillation) or giant cell arteritis.
  • Pathophysiology: Occlusion of the artery leads to acute ischemia of the inner two-thirds of the retina, causing rapid and irreversible death of ganglion cells and other neurons.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden, painless, severe monocular vision loss.
  • Fundoscopy: The classic fundoscopic finding is a pale retina (due to ischemia and edema) with a "cherry-red spot" at the fovea. The cherry-red spot represents the intact choroidal circulation (supplied by the posterior ciliary arteries) visible through the thinned, ischemic fovea.
  • USMLE Tip: The triad of sudden, painless, profound monocular vision loss and a "cherry-red spot" on fundoscopy is pathognomonic for CRAO. It is essentially a stroke of the eye.
content.takeAway: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion is an acute ischemic stroke of the retina, where an embolus blocks its main arterial supply, leading to sudden, devastating vision loss and the iconic fundoscopic image of a pale retina with a contrasting 'cherry-red' macula.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Embolus from Carotid/Heart] --> B(Occlusion of Central Retinal Artery); B --> C(Inner Retinal Ischemia); C --> D(Pale Retina); C --> E(Cherry-Red Spot at Fovea); D & E --> F(Sudden, Painless Vision Loss);

content.definition: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) is a common retinal vascular disorder characterized by the blockage of the central retinal vein at the optic nerve head, leading to venous stasis, retinal hemorrhage, and edema.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The primary mechanism is thrombosis of the central retinal vein, often at the lamina cribrosa where the vein is compressed by a sclerotic central retinal artery with which it shares a common adventitial sheath.
  • Risk Factors: Strongly associated with systemic vascular diseases like hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and glaucoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden, painless, unilateral blurring or loss of vision. The severity can range from mild to severe.
  • Fundoscopy: The fundoscopic exam is dramatic and described as a "blood and thunder" appearance. It shows diffuse, widespread retinal hemorrhages in all four quadrants, venous dilation and tortuosity, cotton-wool spots, and optic disc swelling.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from CRAO: CRVO is a venous 'backup' problem, leading to a hemorrhagic appearance ('blood and thunder'), while CRAO is an arterial 'blockage' problem, leading to a pale, ischemic appearance ('cherry-red spot').
content.takeAway: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion is a vascular 'plumbing backup' in the eye, where a thrombus in the central retinal vein causes a dramatic, widespread backup of blood, resulting in the classic 'blood and thunder' hemorrhagic retinopathy and vision loss.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypertension/Atherosclerosis] --> B(Compression of Central Retinal Vein); B --> C(Thrombosis); C --> D(Central Retinal Vein Occlusion); D --> E(Venous Stasis & ↑ Pressure); E --> F(Diffuse Retinal Hemorrhages & Edema);

content.definition: Central vertigo is a sensation of spinning or dizziness that originates from a problem within the central nervous system, specifically the brainstem or cerebellum. It is generally more serious than peripheral vertigo.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by lesions in the brainstem or cerebellum, such as [[c5da3c57|stroke]] (e.g., lateral medullary syndrome), [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], tumors, or migraines.
  • Nystagmus: The nystagmus in central vertigo can be in any direction (horizontal, torsional, or purely vertical/downbeat). It is often non-fatigable and may change direction with gaze. It is not suppressed by visual fixation.
  • Associated Symptoms: Often accompanied by other neurological signs that point to a central lesion, such as [[9914d433|diplopia]], dysmetria, [[9767fd6b|ataxia]], dysarthria, or focal weakness/sensory loss.
  • Onset: The onset can be sudden or gradual, and the vertigo is often constant and less intense than in peripheral causes.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of purely vertical nystagmus is a red flag and is highly specific for a central cause of vertigo. Also, look for other 'central' neurological signs (the '5 D's': Dizziness, Diplopia, Dysarthria, Dysphagia, Dysmetria).
content.takeAway: Central vertigo is a sign of a CNS lesion, not an inner ear problem. It is distinguished from peripheral vertigo by its associated neurological deficits and a nystagmus that is often vertical and does not suppress with visual fixation, indicating a more ominous underlying cause like a brainstem stroke.

content.definition: Central transtentorial herniation is a type of brain herniation where downward displacement of the cerebral hemispheres, basal ganglia, diencephalon, and midbrain occurs through the tentorial notch. It is typically caused by a diffuse increase in intracranial pressure.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by conditions that increase intracranial pressure symmetrically, such as diffuse cerebral edema, hydrocephalus, or midline tumors.
  • Pathophysiology: The downward pressure causes a sequential caudal displacement of brainstem structures.
  • Clinical Progression:
    1. Early: Altered level of consciousness, small reactive pupils (diencephalic compression).
    2. Later: Mid-position, fixed pupils; decorticate then decerebrate posturing (midbrain/pons compression).
    3. Terminal: Coma, loss of all brainstem reflexes, respiratory arrest (medulla compression).
  • Duret Hemorrhages: A key pathological finding is the presence of Duret hemorrhages, which are secondary brainstem hemorrhages in the pons and midbrain caused by stretching and tearing of perforating arteries during the downward displacement.
  • USMLE Tip: This is a rostrocaudal deterioration. Look for a progressive decline in consciousness accompanied by changes in pupillary response and motor posturing, often culminating in fatal brainstem hemorrhages (Duret hemorrhages).
content.takeAway: Central transtentorial herniation is a devastating downward spiral of the brainstem through the tentorial notch, leading to a predictable sequence of neurological decline from altered consciousness to posturing and death, often marked by the characteristic Duret hemorrhages from vascular shearing.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Intracranial Pressure] --> B(Downward Displacement of Diencephalon/Midbrain); B --> C(Compression of Brainstem); C --> D(Rupture of Paramedian Arteries); D --> E(Duret Hemorrhages);

content.definition: A cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal collection of blood on the scalp of a newborn, caused by the rupture of blood vessels between the skull and the periosteum during birth. It is a common birth trauma, especially with forceps or vacuum-assisted delivery.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: The hemorrhage is located deep to the periosteum (subperiosteal).
  • Clinical Presentation: A firm, well-demarcated swelling on the scalp. A key feature is that it does not cross suture lines, as the periosteum is firmly attached at the sutures.
  • Timing: May not be present at birth but develops over the first few hours to days. It resolves slowly over weeks to months.
  • Complications: The breakdown of the collected red blood cells can lead to jaundice (indirect hyperbilirubinemia). Rarely, it may become calcified.
  • Differentiation: It must be distinguished from a [[a5ec55b5|caput succedaneum]].
    - Cephalohematoma: Firm, does not cross suture lines, appears hours after birth, resolves slowly.
    - Caput Succedaneum: Soft, crosses suture lines, present at birth, resolves quickly.
  • USMLE Tip: The inability to cross suture lines is the most important feature for distinguishing a cephalohematoma from a caput succedaneum on an exam.
content.takeAway: A cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal bleed confined by cranial suture lines, appearing as a firm scalp swelling in a newborn after a difficult delivery; its key distinguishing feature is its respect for suture boundaries, and its main complication is neonatal jaundice.

content.definition: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation is a life-threatening type of brain herniation where the cerebellar tonsils are displaced downward through the foramen magnum, leading to compression of the medulla oblongata.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by a mass or pressure increase in the posterior fossa (e.g., cerebellar tumor, hemorrhage, or edema). It can also be iatrogenically caused by performing a lumbar puncture in the setting of high intracranial pressure.
  • Pathophysiology: The herniating tonsils directly compress the medulla oblongata.
  • Clinical Presentation: This is a rapidly fatal event. Compression of the medullary cardiorespiratory centers leads to bradycardia, respiratory arrest, and death. Patients may also present with headache, neck stiffness, and loss of consciousness.
  • Associated Malformation: This type of herniation is the defining feature of [[b96a6a07|Chiari I and II malformations]], although in those congenital conditions, the process is chronic rather than acute.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic scenario is a patient with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, papilledema) who undergoes a lumbar puncture and then rapidly deteriorates with respiratory arrest. This highlights the danger of LP in the setting of unevaluated increased ICP.
content.takeAway: Cerebellar tonsillar herniation is the most lethal form of brain herniation, as the downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum directly compresses the vital cardiorespiratory centers in the medulla, leading to swift respiratory and cardiac arrest.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Posterior Fossa Pressure] --> B(Cerebellar Tonsils Displace Downward); B --> C(Through Foramen Magnum); C --Compresses--> D(Medulla Oblongata); D --> E(Cardiorespiratory Arrest);

content.definition: Lesions of the cerebellar vermis, the midline portion of the cerebellum, result in a specific set of motor deficits related to the control of the trunk and axial musculature, as well as eye movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomical Correlation: The vermis is centrally located and primarily controls the central body (trunk).
  • Hallmark Sign: Truncal ataxia. This manifests as an unsteady, wide-based gait often described as a "drunken sailor" gait. Patients have difficulty sitting or standing upright without swaying or falling.
  • Ocular Signs: Nystagmus and other impairments of eye movement control are common due to the vermis's connections with the vestibular nuclei.
  • Speech: Dysarthria (slurred, uncoordinated speech) can also occur.
  • Etiology: In adults, degeneration of the vermis is classically associated with chronic alcohol overuse. In children, a [[16d613bb|medulloblastoma]] is a common cause of a vermal lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate vermal lesions from cerebellar hemisphere lesions. Vermis lesion = truncal ataxia (midline problems). Hemisphere lesion = limb ataxia, intention tremor (lateral problems).
content.takeAway: A lesion of the cerebellar vermis selectively impairs control of the body's midline, leading to a profound truncal ataxia that makes stable standing and walking difficult, a presentation classically linked to chronic alcoholism in adults or medulloblastoma in children.

content.definition: The Cerebellum (Latin for "little brain") is a major feature of the hindbrain located posterior to the pons and medulla. It plays a crucial role in modulating motor commands to control balance, coordination, and precision of voluntary movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Modulates movement; aids in coordination, balance, and motor learning. It does not initiate movement but fine-tunes it.
  • Anatomical Divisions:
    - Vermis (midline): Controls axial and proximal limb musculature (truncal stability).
    - Hemispheres (lateral): Control distal limb musculature (limb coordination).
    - Flocculonodular Lobe: Involved in balance and eye movements via connections with the vestibular system.
  • Input/Output: Receives proprioceptive input from the spinal cord (ipsilateral) and motor plan input from the contralateral cortex. It sends output to the contralateral cortex via the thalamus to modulate movement. Each cerebellar hemisphere controls the ipsilateral side of the body.
  • Lesions: Cerebellar lesions cause ipsilateral deficits. Vermal lesions cause truncal ataxia. Hemispheric lesions cause limb ataxia, dysmetria, and intention tremor.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that cerebellar signs are ipsilateral to the lesion. A patient who falls to the left has a left-sided cerebellar lesion.
content.takeAway: The Cerebellum acts as the brain's master coordinator, comparing the intended movement from the cortex with the actual movement from proprioceptive feedback, and issuing corrective signals to ensure smooth, balanced, and accurate motor activity.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cortex] --Motor Plan--> B(Cerebellum); C[Spinal Cord] --Proprioception--> B; B --Corrective Signals--> A;

content.definition: The Cerebral Aqueduct (also known as the Aqueduct of Sylvius) is a narrow channel within the midbrain that connects the third ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle in the hindbrain, allowing for the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Traverses the midbrain.
  • Function: Serves as a conduit for CSF flow from the third to the fourth ventricle.
  • Clinical Significance: Due to its narrow diameter, the cerebral aqueduct is a common site for obstruction, leading to non-communicating hydrocephalus.
  • Causes of Stenosis:
    - Congenital: Can be congenitally narrow (aqueductal stenosis), sometimes as an X-linked condition.
    - Acquired: Can be compressed by tumors (e.g., pinealoma, brainstem glioma) or blocked by inflammation/hemorrhage.
  • Presentation of Obstruction: In infants, presents with an enlarging head circumference. In adults, presents with signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, papilledema, vomiting).
  • USMLE Tip: A CT or MRI showing enlarged lateral and third ventricles with a normal-sized fourth ventricle is the classic imaging finding for aqueductal stenosis.
content.takeAway: The Cerebral Aqueduct is a critical but vulnerable bottleneck in the CSF pathway; its obstruction leads to a backup of CSF and non-communicating hydrocephalus, effectively damming the flow between the third and fourth ventricles.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Ventricles] --> B(Third Ventricle); B --> C(Cerebral Aqueduct); C --Obstruction--> D(Non-communicating Hydrocephalus); C --> E(Fourth Ventricle);

content.definition: The Cerebral Arteries are the network of blood vessels that supply oxygenated blood to the brain. They are broadly divided into the anterior circulation (derived from the internal carotid arteries) and the posterior circulation (derived from the vertebral arteries), which are connected by the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]].
content.atAGlance:
• Anterior Circulation: Includes the [[830c856c|Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA)]] and the [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].
  • Posterior Circulation: Includes the vertebral arteries, the [[e7a90cd9|basilar artery]], and the [[b6a2cc31|Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA)]].
  • Cortical Distribution: Each major artery supplies a distinct territory of the cerebral cortex:
    - ACA: Medial surface of the frontal and parietal lobes (supplying the leg/foot area of the motor/sensory homunculus).
    - MCA: Lateral surface of the hemispheres (supplying the face/arm/hand area and language centers).
    - PCA: Occipital lobe and inferior surface of the temporal lobe (supplying the visual cortex).
  • Watershed Zones: Areas at the border between two major arterial territories (e.g., ACA-MCA) are vulnerable to ischemia during systemic hypoperfusion, leading to watershed infarcts.
  • USMLE Tip: Knowing the cortical distribution of the ACA, MCA, and PCA is essential for localizing stroke lesions from clinical symptoms.
content.takeAway: The brain's arterial supply is precisely organized, with the cerebral arteries each irrigating specific functional territories; this anatomical consistency allows clinicians to predict the location of a stroke based on the patient's neurological deficits.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Circle of Willis] --> B(Anterior Cerebral Artery); A --> C(Middle Cerebral Artery); A --> D(Posterior Cerebral Artery);

content.definition: The Cerebral Cortex is the outermost layer of the cerebrum, composed of gray matter (neuronal cell bodies). It is responsible for higher-order brain functions, including consciousness, thought, language, memory, and sensation.
content.atAGlance:
• Lobes: Divided into four main lobes: Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, and Occipital.
  • Functional Regions: Contains specialized areas for processing different types of information:
    - Frontal Lobe: Motor control (primary motor cortex), executive function (prefrontal cortex), speech production ([[a3bbace2|Broca's area]]).
    - Parietal Lobe: Somatosensation (primary somatosensory cortex), spatial awareness.
    - Temporal Lobe: Audition ([[d24b6af6|auditory cortex]]), language comprehension ([[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]]), memory ([[a0590674|hippocampus]]).
    - Occipital Lobe: Vision (primary visual cortex).
  • Arterial Distribution: Supplied by the [[e51a7691|cerebral arteries]]: [[830c856c|ACA]] (medial), [[143bb23d|MCA]] (lateral), [[b6a2cc31|PCA]] (posterior/inferior).
  • Clinical Syndromes: Lesions produce specific deficits, e.g., [[6bc9a567|aphasia]] (dominant hemisphere), hemineglect (non-dominant parietal lobe), [[ff289b3a|visual field defects]].
  • USMLE Tip: The homunculus is a key concept, mapping motor and sensory functions of the body onto the precentral and postcentral gyri, respectively.
content.takeAway: The Cerebral Cortex is the seat of higher cognition, with its intricately folded surface housing specialized regions for every aspect of conscious experience, from moving a finger to understanding language.

content.definition: Cerebral edema is the accumulation of excess fluid in the intracellular or extracellular spaces of the brain, leading to an increase in brain volume and intracranial pressure (ICP).
content.atAGlance:
• Vasogenic Edema: The most common type. Caused by the breakdown of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]], allowing plasma proteins and fluid to leak into the extracellular space. Occurs with tumors, inflammation, and late-stage [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]].
  • Cytotoxic Edema: Involves swelling of the brain cells themselves (intracellular edema) due to failure of the Na+/K+ pump, leading to an influx of Na+ and water. Occurs early in [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] and other toxic/metabolic insults.
  • Clinical Consequences: Increased ICP can cause headache, vomiting, altered consciousness, and can lead to life-threatening [[8c0728b7|brain herniation]].
  • Treatment: Management aims to reduce ICP. This includes head elevation, osmotic therapy (mannitol, hypertonic saline), and therapeutic hyperventilation.
  • Therapeutic Hyperventilation: Intentionally lowering PaCO2 causes cerebral vasoconstriction, which reduces cerebral blood flow and thereby decreases ICP. This is a temporary measure.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the two main types: Vasogenic = leaky vessels (extracellular fluid), Cytotoxic = sick cells (intracellular fluid).
content.takeAway: Cerebral edema is a dangerous swelling of the brain that can be either vasogenic (leaky vessels) or cytotoxic (swollen cells), both of which increase intracranial pressure and risk herniation; management strategies like hyperventilation work by manipulating cerebral blood flow to reduce brain volume.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brain Insult] --> B{Types of Edema}; B --> C[Vasogenic]; C --> D(↑ BBB Permeability); D --> E(Extracellular Fluid); B --> F[Cytotoxic]; F --> G(Na+/K+ Pump Failure); G --> H(Intracellular Fluid); E & H --> I(↑ Intracranial Pressure);

content.definition: Cerebral Palsy (CP) is a non-progressive disorder of movement, muscle tone, or posture caused by damage to the immature, developing brain, most often before birth. It is the most common motor disability in childhood.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: A static (non-progressive) brain lesion that occurs prenatally, perinatally, or in early infancy. Major risk factors include prematurity and low birth weight. Other causes include intrauterine infections, birth asphyxia, and neonatal stroke.
  • Clinical Presentation: The primary feature is impaired motor function. The type of motor impairment depends on the location of the brain injury:
    - Spastic CP (most common): UMN lesion signs (spasticity, hyperreflexia).
    - Dyskinetic CP: Basal ganglia damage (athetosis, chorea).
    - Ataxic CP: Cerebellar damage (ataxia, incoordination).
  • Associated Conditions: Patients often have associated comorbidities, including intellectual disability, seizures, and sensory impairments (vision, hearing).
  • Treatment: Management is multidisciplinary and supportive, aimed at maximizing function. Treatments for spasticity include physical therapy, oral medications ([[1ddc3f08|baclofen]], tizanidine), and [[84b10400|botulinum toxin]] injections.
  • USMLE Tip: Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive motor disorder. If a child's motor symptoms are worsening over time, another diagnosis should be considered. Prematurity is the single most important risk factor.
content.takeAway: Cerebral Palsy is a permanent but non-progressive motor disorder resulting from an early-life brain injury, manifesting as a spectrum of movement and posture problems, with spasticity being the most common presentation.

content.definition: Cerebral perfusion refers to the blood flow to the brain tissue. It is tightly autoregulated to ensure a constant supply of oxygen and glucose, and is primarily driven by the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) and influenced by chemical factors, most notably PaCO2.
content.atAGlance:
• Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP): The net pressure gradient driving blood flow to the brain. It is calculated as: CPP = Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP). A normal CPP is >60 mmHg.
  • Autoregulation: Cerebral blood flow (CBF) is kept relatively constant over a wide range of MAP (approx. 60-140 mmHg). Outside this range, CBF becomes pressure-dependent.
  • Chemical Regulation:
    - PaCO2: The most potent regulator of CBF. Hypercapnia (↑ PaCO2) causes vasodilation and ↑ CBF. Hypocapnia (↓ PaCO2) causes vasoconstriction and ↓ CBF.
    - PaO2: Has little effect unless severe hypoxia (PaO2 < 50 mmHg) occurs, which causes marked vasodilation and ↑ CBF.
  • Clinical Application: In patients with increased ICP, therapeutic hyperventilation is used to induce hypocapnia, causing vasoconstriction and a temporary reduction in ICP.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the direct relationship between PaCO2 and cerebral blood flow. This is the physiological basis for using hyperventilation to manage acute cerebral edema.
content.takeAway: Cerebral perfusion is a tightly controlled process where the brain maintains its own blood flow despite fluctuations in systemic pressure, with carbon dioxide levels acting as the most powerful local controller of cerebral vessel diameter.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[MAP] --> B(CPP); C[ICP] --> B; B --> D(Cerebral Blood Flow); E[PaCO2] --Potent Regulator--> D;

content.definition: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure (CPP) is the net pressure gradient that drives blood flow to the brain. It is a critical parameter in the management of patients with brain injury, as inadequate CPP can lead to cerebral ischemia.
content.atAGlance:
• Formula: CPP = Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) - Intracranial Pressure (ICP).
  • Normal Value: A normal CPP is typically maintained between 60 and 80 mmHg. A CPP below 50-60 mmHg can result in cerebral ischemia.
  • Relationship with CBF: Cerebral blood flow (CBF) is directly proportional to CPP and inversely proportional to cerebral vascular resistance (CVR). (CBF = CPP / CVR).
  • Clinical Management: In patients with elevated ICP (e.g., from trauma, hemorrhage, or [[aa00bdef|cerebral edema]]), management focuses on both lowering ICP (e.g., mannitol, hyperventilation) and maintaining an adequate MAP (e.g., with vasopressors) to ensure sufficient CPP.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the formula. If a patient's MAP drops or their ICP rises, their CPP will decrease, putting them at risk for brain ischemia. If CPP = 0, there is no cerebral perfusion, which is consistent with [[1777e176|brain death]].
content.takeAway: Cerebral Perfusion Pressure is the critical driving force for brain blood flow, representing the balance between the systemic pressure pushing blood in (MAP) and the intracranial pressure pushing back (ICP); maintaining this pressure is paramount in neurocritical care.

content.definition: Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) is a clear, colorless body fluid found in the brain and spinal cord. It is produced by the choroid plexus, circulates through the ventricular system and subarachnoid space, and is eventually reabsorbed into the venous circulation, providing buoyancy, protection, and chemical stability for the CNS.
content.atAGlance:
• Production: Produced by the choroid plexus within the ventricles at a rate of about 20 mL/hr.
  • Circulation Pathway: Lateral ventricles → foramen of Monro → third ventricle → [[8a30e721|cerebral aqueduct]] → fourth ventricle → foramina of Luschka & Magendie → subarachnoid space.
  • Reabsorption: Reabsorbed into the venous circulation via the [[b7b67074|arachnoid granulations]], which project into the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Normal Composition: Clear, colorless, with very few cells (<5 lymphocytes/mm3), low protein (<45 mg/dL), and glucose that is approximately 2/3 of the serum glucose level.
  • Diagnostic Use: CSF analysis via lumbar puncture is crucial for diagnosing meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], and other CNS disorders. For example, [[a0f3ce4c|albuminocytologic dissociation]] is seen in Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the characteristic CSF findings for different types of meningitis: Bacterial (↑ PMNs, ↓ glucose, ↑ protein), Viral (↑ lymphocytes, normal glucose), Fungal/TB (↑ lymphocytes, ↓ glucose).
content.takeAway: Cerebrospinal Fluid is the brain's life-support system, providing a protective cushion and a stable chemical environment through a continuous cycle of production by the choroid plexus, circulation through the ventricles, and reabsorption by the arachnoid granulations.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Production--> B(CSF in Ventricles); B --Circulation--> C(Subarachnoid Space); C --Reabsorption--> D(Arachnoid Granulations); D --> E[Venous Sinuses];

content.definition: A chalazion is a common, benign, inflammatory lump in the eyelid caused by a blocked meibomian gland. It is a granulomatous reaction to the lipids that leak from the obstructed gland.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Obstruction of a meibomian gland (a modified sebaceous gland in the tarsal plate) leads to leakage of lipid contents into the surrounding tissue, inciting a granulomatous inflammatory response.
  • Clinical Presentation: A firm, rubbery, painless nodule within the eyelid. It is typically slow-growing and not located on the eyelid margin itself.
  • Differentiation from Hordeolum (Stye): A [[hordeolum]] is an acute, painful, pyogenic (usually staphylococcal) infection of an eyelid gland, presenting as a tender red bump on the eyelid margin. A chalazion is a non-infectious, painless, granulomatous inflammation located within the eyelid.
  • Treatment: Most resolve spontaneously with conservative treatment, including warm compresses and gentle massage to help liquefy the trapped lipids and promote drainage. Persistent or large lesions may require incision and curettage or a glucocorticoid injection.
  • USMLE Tip: The key distinguishing feature from a stye is that a chalazion is painless and granulomatous, whereas a hordeolum is painful and infectious.
content.takeAway: A chalazion is a sterile, granulomatous 'lump' resulting from a blocked oil gland in the eyelid, presenting as a painless nodule that is fundamentally an inflammatory reaction, not an infection like a hordeolum.

content.definition: A Charcot joint, also known as neuropathic arthropathy, is a condition characterized by progressive destruction and deformity of a joint, resulting from a loss of protective sensation (proprioception and pain).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The loss of pain and position sense leads to recurrent, unrecognized microtrauma to the joint. This triggers a cycle of inflammation, bone resorption, and remodeling, ultimately leading to severe joint destruction, instability, and deformity.
  • Common Causes: Any condition that causes peripheral neuropathy can lead to a Charcot joint. The most common cause is diabetes mellitus (affecting the foot and ankle). Other classic causes include [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] (tertiary syphilis, affecting the knee) and [[syringomyelia]] (affecting the shoulder).
  • Clinical Presentation: The affected joint is typically swollen, warm, and erythematous, but is often surprisingly painless or has less pain than expected given the degree of destruction.
  • Radiology: X-rays show classic findings of severe degenerative changes, bone fragmentation, subluxation, and dislocation.
  • USMLE Tip: When a question describes a severely deformed, swollen, but relatively painless joint, think of Charcot joint. The next step is to identify the underlying cause of the neuropathy (e.g., diabetes, syphilis).
content.takeAway: A Charcot joint is the devastating consequence of a joint that cannot feel pain; without the protective feedback of sensation, repeated trauma leads to a vicious cycle of inflammation and bone destruction, resulting in a grossly deformed and unstable joint.

content.definition: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are minute aneurysms of the small, penetrating (lenticulostriate) arteries in the brain that are strongly associated with chronic hypertension. Their rupture is a major cause of hypertensive [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Chronic hypertension leads to hyaline arteriosclerosis, which weakens the walls of small penetrating arteries, causing them to form small outpouchings (microaneurysms).
  • Location: Most commonly affect the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the deep brain structures. Therefore, hemorrhages typically occur in the basal ganglia (putamen), thalamus, pons, and cerebellum.
  • Clinical Consequence: Rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm leads to a spontaneous, hypertensive [[70b266c8|intraparenchymal hemorrhage]].
  • Differentiation: These are distinct from [[a9f6d703|saccular (berry) aneurysms]], which are larger, occur in the Circle of Willis, and cause subarachnoid hemorrhage. Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are too small to be seen on angiography.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with a long history of poorly controlled hypertension who presents with a sudden focal neurological deficit and a CT scan showing a deep brain hemorrhage (e.g., in the basal ganglia) has likely ruptured a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm.
content.takeAway: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are the vascular consequence of chronic hypertension on the brain's smallest arteries; these tiny, fragile aneurysms are prone to rupture, causing devastating deep intracerebral hemorrhages.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chronic Hypertension] --> B(Hyaline Arteriosclerosis); B --> C(Weakening of Lenticulostriate Arteries); C --> D(Charcot-Bouchard Microaneurysm); D --Rupture--> E(Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage);

content.definition: Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease, also known as hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy (HMSN), is a group of inherited disorders of the peripheral nervous system characterized by progressive weakness and sensory loss, predominantly affecting the distal extremities.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: The most common inherited neuropathy. It has multiple genetic forms, with the most common type, CMT1A, being an autosomal dominant condition caused by a duplication of the PMP22 gene.
  • Pathophysiology: The genetic defects lead to abnormal myelin sheath (demyelinating types like CMT1) or direct axonal damage (axonal types like CMT2). Demyelinating types show 'onion bulb' formations on nerve biopsy due to repeated demyelination and remyelination.
  • Clinical Presentation: Insidious onset, typically in adolescence or early adulthood. Presents with distal muscle weakness and atrophy, starting in the legs. This leads to foot drop, a steppage gait, and characteristic foot deformities like pes cavus (high arches) and hammer toes.
  • Sensory Loss: There is often a 'glove and stocking' pattern of sensory loss, particularly affecting vibration and proprioception.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic presentation is a young patient with progressive distal leg weakness, foot drop, high-arched feet (pes cavus), and sensory loss. The family history is often positive. Mnemonic: Can't Move Toes for CMT.
content.takeAway: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease is a genetic neuropathy that slowly 'whittles away' the peripheral nerves, starting from the feet and hands and moving proximally, leading to the classic clinical picture of distal muscle atrophy (stork legs), foot drop, and high-arched feet.
