    - Lacunar: Occlusion of small, penetrating arteries, often due to hypertension.
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke (~15%): Caused by rupture of a blood vessel.
    - [[70b266c8|Intraparenchymal]]: Bleeding into the brain tissue, often from rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms due to hypertension.
    - [[63f8b05f|Subarachnoid]]: Bleeding into the subarachnoid space, often from a ruptured berry aneurysm.
  • Presentation: Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits. The specific symptoms depend on the lesion area and affected vascular territory.
  • Diagnosis: Immediate non-contrast head CT is crucial to differentiate ischemic from hemorrhagic stroke, as this guides acute management.
  • Acute Treatment: For ischemic stroke, thrombolysis with tPA (tissue plasminogen activator) may be an option if within the therapeutic window (typically 3-4.5 hours).
  • USMLE Tip: [[714f15fc|Central post-stroke pain]] is a potential chronic complication, especially after a thalamic stroke.
content.takeAway: A stroke is a 'brain attack' that causes neurological deficits corresponding to the affected vascular territory; the immediate priority is to distinguish ischemic from hemorrhagic types with a CT scan, as the acute treatments are diametrically opposed.

content.definition: Sturge-Weber syndrome, also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a rare, congenital neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and an associated vascular malformation of the brain and eye.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Caused by a somatic mosaic mutation in the [[5ef5ca57|GNAQ]] gene. It is not inherited.
  • Classic Triad:
    1. Facial Port-Wine Stain: A capillary malformation in the distribution of the ophthalmic (V1) and sometimes maxillary (V2) branches of the trigeminal nerve.
    2. Leptomeningeal Angioma: An abnormal collection of blood vessels on the surface of the brain, typically ipsilateral to the facial lesion. This can lead to seizures (most common neurological symptom), intellectual disability, and focal neurological deficits.
    3. Glaucoma: Increased intraocular pressure, often ipsilateral to the facial lesion.
  • Imaging: Skull X-rays or CT scans may show characteristic 'tram-track' calcifications, which represent calcification of the cortex underlying the leptomeningeal angioma.
  • USMLE Tip: A child with a port-wine stain on their face, seizures, and intellectual disability is the classic presentation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
content.takeAway: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a congenital vascular disorder that 'stains' the face with a port-wine birthmark and the underlying brain with a leptomeningeal angioma, leading to a triad of dermatological, neurological (seizures), and ophthalmological (glaucoma) problems.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Somatic GNAQ Mutation] --> B(Vascular Malformation); B --> C(Facial Port-Wine Stain); B --> D(Leptomeningeal Angioma); D --> E(Seizures); B --> F(Ocular Involvement); F --> G(Glaucoma);

content.definition: Subacute Combined Degeneration (SCD) is a neurological complication of severe [[784e2484|vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency]]. It is characterized by the progressive demyelination of specific tracts in the spinal cord.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid, which is thought to be toxic to myelin. This results in demyelination of three main spinal cord tracts.
  • Affected Tracts:
    1. [[e7f5cbbe|Dorsal Columns]]: Causes loss of proprioception and vibration sense, leading to sensory ataxia and a positive Romberg sign.
    2. Lateral Corticospinal Tracts: Causes upper motor neuron signs, such as spastic paresis and hyperreflexia.
    3. Spinocerebellar Tracts: Contributes to ataxia.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients present with a combination of sensory ataxia (from dorsal column loss) and spastic weakness (from corticospinal tract loss).
  • Associated Findings: Often accompanied by megaloblastic anemia, but neurological symptoms can precede or occur in the absence of hematological changes.
  • USMLE Tip: The 'combined' in the name refers to the combination of damage to both ascending (dorsal columns) and descending (corticospinal) tracts. Remember that folate supplementation can correct the anemia of B12 deficiency but will not stop (and may worsen) the progression of SCD.
content.takeAway: Subacute Combined Degeneration is the devastating neurological consequence of vitamin B12 deficiency, where demyelination of both the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord leads to a crippling combination of sensory ataxia and spastic weakness.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vitamin B12 Deficiency] --> B(↑ Methylmalonic Acid); B --> C(Myelin Damage); C --> D(Demyelination of Spinal Cord Tracts); D --> E(Dorsal Columns -> Sensory Ataxia); D --> F(Corticospinal Tracts -> Spastic Paresis);

content.definition: A subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, the area between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater that is normally filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It is a type of hemorrhagic stroke and a medical emergency.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: The most common cause of non-traumatic SAH is the rupture of a saccular [[a9f6d703|berry aneurysm]] (~85% of cases). Other causes include trauma (most common overall), arteriovenous malformations, and vasculitis.
  • Clinical Presentation: Characterized by the sudden onset of a severe, explosive headache, classically described as the "worst headache of my life" or a 'thunderclap headache.' May be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and nuchal rigidity.
  • Diagnosis:
    1. Non-contrast head CT: The initial test of choice. Shows hyperdense (white) blood in the sulci and basal cisterns.
    2. Lumbar Puncture: Performed if the CT is negative but clinical suspicion is high. The classic finding is xanthochromia (yellowish discoloration of the CSF due to bilirubin from RBC breakdown), which appears several hours after the bleed.
  • Complications:
    - Rebleeding: High risk in the first 24 hours.
    - Vasospasm: Narrowing of cerebral arteries 3-10 days after the bleed, which can cause ischemic stroke. Nimodipine (a calcium channel blocker) is used to prevent this.
    - Hydrocephalus: Blood can obstruct CSF reabsorption at the arachnoid granulations.
  • USMLE Tip: 'Worst headache of my life' = Subarachnoid hemorrhage. The first step is a non-contrast CT. If negative, the next step is a lumbar puncture.
content.takeAway: A subarachnoid hemorrhage is a neurovascular catastrophe, most often from a ruptured berry aneurysm, that announces itself with a 'thunderclap headache' and carries the dual threats of rebleeding and delayed ischemic stroke from vasospasm.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Ruptured Berry Aneurysm] --> B(Bleeding into Subarachnoid Space); B --> C(Sudden ↑ ICP); C --> D(Worst Headache of My Life);

content.definition: The subarachnoid space is the anatomical space between the [[46e279b9|arachnoid mater]] and the pia mater. It is filled with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and contains the major arteries and veins of the brain.
content.atAGlance:
• Contents: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), major cerebral arteries (forming the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]]), and bridging veins.
  • Function: The CSF within this space provides a buoyant cushion for the brain, protecting it from trauma.
  • CSF Circulation: CSF enters the subarachnoid space from the fourth ventricle via the foramina of Luschka and Magendie and is reabsorbed into the dural venous sinuses via the [[b7b67074|arachnoid granulations]].
  • Clinical Significance:
    - [[63f8b05f|Subarachnoid Hemorrhage]]: Bleeding into this space, typically from a ruptured aneurysm.
    - Meningitis: Inflammation of the meninges, with inflammatory cells found in the CSF of the subarachnoid space.
    - Lumbar Puncture: A needle is inserted into the lumbar subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern) to sample CSF.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that the major blood vessels of the brain run through the subarachnoid space, which is why a ruptured aneurysm bleeds into this space.
content.takeAway: The subarachnoid space is the CSF-filled 'moat' surrounding the brain, providing a protective fluid buffer and serving as the conduit for the brain's major blood vessels, but also making it the site of devastating hemorrhages and infections.

content.definition: A subdural hematoma (SDH) is a collection of blood that forms between the inner layer of the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. It is typically caused by the tearing of bridging veins that cross the subdural space.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Usually caused by head trauma, often with acceleration-deceleration forces that shear the bridging veins. It is common in the elderly (due to brain atrophy, which stretches the veins) and in infants (shaken baby syndrome). Chronic alcohol use is also a risk factor.
  • Pathophysiology: Venous bleeding leads to a slower accumulation of blood compared to an epidural hematoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Can be acute, subacute, or chronic. Symptoms may be insidious and fluctuating, including headache, confusion, somnolence, and focal neurological deficits.
  • Imaging: A non-contrast head CT shows a hyperdense (acute) or hypodense (chronic), crescent-shaped blood collection that crosses suture lines but is limited by dural reflections (e.g., falx cerebri).
  • USMLE Tip: Crescent shape that crosses suture lines = Subdural hematoma. Lentiform shape that does not cross suture lines = [[a61683ae|Epidural hematoma]]. The classic patient is an elderly individual with a history of a fall who presents with gradual cognitive decline.
content.takeAway: A subdural hematoma is a low-pressure venous bleed from torn bridging veins, which slowly spreads in a crescent shape over the brain's surface and is classically seen in the elderly after minor head trauma due to age-related brain atrophy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Head Trauma] --> B(Tearing of Bridging Veins); B --> C(Venous Bleeding into Subdural Space); C --> D(Crescent-shaped Hematoma); D --> E(Compression of Brain);

content.definition: A subgaleal hemorrhage is a rare but potentially lethal extracranial hemorrhage in a newborn, where blood accumulates in the potential space between the cranial periosteum and the galea aponeurosis.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Caused by the rupture of emissary veins, which connect the dural sinuses with the scalp veins. It is a severe complication of difficult operative vaginal deliveries, especially vacuum extraction.
  • Pathophysiology: The subgaleal space is large and can accommodate a significant portion of the infant's total blood volume, leading to severe hemorrhagic shock.
  • Clinical Presentation: Presents with a diffuse, fluctuant, boggy swelling of the scalp that crosses suture lines and can shift with gravity. The infant may show signs of hypovolemic shock (tachycardia, pallor, poor perfusion).
  • Complications: Hypovolemic shock, coagulopathy, and death.
  • USMLE Tip: A newborn with a rapidly expanding, boggy scalp swelling that crosses suture lines after a difficult vacuum delivery should raise immediate concern for a subgaleal hemorrhage, a life-threatening emergency.
content.takeAway: A subgaleal hemorrhage is a dangerous neonatal bleed into the vast potential space under the scalp aponeurosis, capable of causing rapid and massive blood loss and hypovolemic shock, most often as a complication of vacuum-assisted delivery.

content.definition: Substance P is a neuropeptide of the tachykinin family that functions as a neurotransmitter and neuromodulator. It is strongly associated with the transmission of pain signals and the inflammatory response.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: A key mediator in the perception of pain. It is released from the peripheral terminals of sensory nerve fibers (nociceptors) in response to noxious stimuli and in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord to transmit pain signals to higher centers.
  • Receptor: It acts on the neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptor.
  • Role in Migraine: Along with [[24d36d58|CGRP]], substance P is one of the vasoactive neuropeptides released from trigeminal nerve endings during a [[c8833bae|migraine]] attack, contributing to neurogenic inflammation and pain.
  • Role in Vomiting: Substance P acting on NK-1 receptors in the brainstem (vomiting center) is a key mediator of the vomiting reflex, particularly in delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.
  • Pharmacology: NK-1 receptor antagonists (e.g., aprepitant) are used as antiemetics. Topical [[e4b8298b|capsaicin]] works by depleting substance P from peripheral nerve endings to produce analgesia.
  • USMLE Tip: Associate Substance P with pain transmission in the spinal cord and its role in both migraine and emesis.
content.takeAway: Substance P is the primary neuropeptide for pain signaling, released by nociceptive neurons to transmit pain information centrally, and its blockade is a therapeutic strategy for both pain and emesis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Noxious Stimulus] --> B(Nociceptor); B --Releases Substance P--> C(Dorsal Horn Neuron); C --> D(Ascending Pain Pathway);

content.definition: A lesion of the subthalamic nucleus (STN), a component of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], results in a hyperkinetic movement disorder known as hemiballismus.
content.atAGlance:
• Function of STN: The STN is the key excitatory nucleus in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia. It provides excitatory (glutamatergic) input to the globus pallidus internus (GPi), which in turn inhibits the thalamus to suppress unwanted movements.
  • Lesion Pathophysiology: A lesion of the STN (typically a lacunar stroke) removes this excitatory drive to the GPi. This leads to reduced inhibitory output from the GPi to the thalamus. The resulting disinhibition of the thalamus causes excessive cortical excitation and involuntary movements.
  • Clinical Presentation (Hemiballismus): Characterized by wild, violent, flinging movements of the limbs on one side of the body (contralateral to the lesion).
  • USMLE Tip: Contralateral hemiballismus is the classic, pathognomonic sign of a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.
content.takeAway: A lesion in the subthalamic nucleus effectively 'cuts the brakes' of the indirect pathway, leading to a profound disinhibition of the thalamus and the explosive, uncontrolled, flinging movements of contralateral hemiballismus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lesion of Subthalamic Nucleus] --x B(Excitation of GPi); B --x C(Inhibition of Thalamus); C --> D(Disinhibition of Thalamus); D --> E(Contralateral Hemiballismus);

content.definition: Succinylcholine is the only depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent in clinical use. It induces paralysis by causing persistent depolarization of the motor endplate.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action (Phase I): Acts as a nicotinic ACh receptor agonist. It binds to the receptor, causing initial depolarization which leads to transient muscle twitching (fasciculations). Because it is not degraded by acetylcholinesterase, it remains bound, keeping the membrane depolarized and preventing repolarization, leading to flaccid paralysis.
  • Mechanism of Action (Phase II): With prolonged exposure, the receptor becomes desensitized, and the membrane repolarizes but remains unresponsive to ACh.
  • Clinical Use: Used for rapid sequence intubation due to its fast onset (~1 min) and short duration (~5-10 min).
  • Metabolism: Rapidly hydrolyzed by plasma pseudocholinesterase (butyrylcholinesterase).
  • Adverse Effects:
    - Malignant Hyperthermia: A life-threatening hypermetabolic state in genetically susceptible individuals.
    - Hyperkalemia: Can cause a dangerous increase in serum potassium, especially in patients with burns, crush injuries, or neuromuscular diseases, due to upregulation of ACh receptors.
    - Bradycardia or tachycardia.
  • USMLE Tip: The initial muscle fasciculations are the key clinical feature that distinguishes succinylcholine from non-depolarizing blockers. Its potential to cause malignant hyperthermia and severe hyperkalemia are high-yield adverse effects.
content.takeAway: Succinylcholine is a unique neuromuscular blocker that paralyzes muscles by overstimulating them into a state of persistent depolarization, offering a rapid onset and offset ideal for intubation but carrying the serious risks of malignant hyperthermia and life-threatening hyperkalemia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Succinylcholine] --> B(Binds Nicotinic ACh Receptor); B --> C(Phase I: Depolarization); C --> D(Fasciculations); D --> E(Flaccid Paralysis);

content.definition: The sucking reflex is a primitive reflex present in infants that allows for feeding. It is characterized by a sucking motion when the roof of the mouth is stimulated.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: Elicited by placing a gloved finger or pacifier into the infant's mouth and touching the palate.
  • Normal Response: The infant will begin to suck rhythmically.
  • Timeline: Present at birth and is strongest in the first few months. It is gradually replaced by voluntary sucking and typically disappears by 4 months of age.
  • Clinical Significance: It is one of several primitive reflexes tested in the newborn neurological exam to assess brainstem function and development. A weak or absent sucking reflex can be a sign of prematurity or neurological impairment.
  • Re-emergence: The reappearance of the sucking reflex in an adult is an abnormal finding known as a frontal release sign, indicating damage to the [[0405ada3|frontal lobe]].
  • USMLE Tip: The sucking reflex is a normal, essential reflex for feeding in a newborn. Its persistence or re-emergence in an older child or adult is pathological.
content.takeAway: The sucking reflex is an innate, brainstem-mediated survival reflex in infants that ensures feeding, which is later suppressed by the maturing frontal lobes; its reappearance in adulthood is a sign of frontal lobe pathology.

content.definition: Sumatriptan is the prototypical drug in the triptan class, acting as a serotonin 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist. It is a first-line therapy for the acute (abortive) treatment of moderate to severe [[c8833bae|migraine]] and [[21760f80|cluster headaches]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action:
    1. Agonism at 5-HT1B receptors on cranial blood vessels causes vasoconstriction, counteracting the vasodilation thought to contribute to migraine pain.
    2. Agonism at presynaptic 5-HT1D receptors on trigeminal nerve endings inhibits the release of vasoactive neuropeptides like CGRP.
  • Clinical Use: Acute treatment of [[c8833bae|migraines]] (with or without aura) and [[21760f80|cluster headaches]]. It is not for prophylaxis.
  • Adverse Effects: Paresthesias, dizziness, and 'triptan sensations' (a feeling of tightness or pressure in the chest, neck, or throat).
  • Contraindications: Due to its vasoconstrictive effects, it is contraindicated in patients with a history of coronary artery disease, uncontrolled hypertension, or stroke.
  • USMLE Tip: Sumatriptan is the classic abortive agent for migraines and cluster headaches. Its vasoconstrictive properties are both part of its mechanism and the source of its major contraindications.
content.takeAway: Sumatriptan provides rapid relief from migraine and cluster headaches by constricting cranial vessels and blocking pain peptide release, but this powerful vasoconstriction makes it unsafe for patients with underlying cardiovascular disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Sumatriptan] --> B(5-HT1B/1D Agonist); B --> C(Cranial Vasoconstriction); B --> D(↓ CGRP Release); C & D --> E(Migraine/Cluster Headache Relief);

content.definition: The Superior Oblique is one of the six extraocular muscles. It is unique in that it passes through a fibrocartilaginous pulley, the trochlea, before inserting on the eyeball, and it is innervated by the [[bba6093a|trochlear nerve (CN IV)]].
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation: Innervated by the contralateral [[bba6093a|trochlear nerve (CN IV)]].
  • Actions: Its primary action is intorsion (internal rotation of the top of the eye toward the nose). Its secondary action is depression (especially in adduction), and its tertiary action is abduction.
  • Testing: The depressing action of the superior oblique is best isolated by having the patient look down and in (adducted position).
  • Palsy: A [[de532715|CN IV palsy]] results in weakness of the superior oblique. The eye becomes extorted and elevated (hypertropia). This causes vertical [[9914d433|diplopia]] that is worse when looking down and medially (e.g., reading or going down stairs). Patients compensate by tilting their head away from the affected side.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the mnemonic (SO4LR6)3: Superior Oblique is innervated by CN IV.
content.takeAway: The Superior Oblique muscle, controlled by the trochlear nerve, is the eye's primary intortor and is crucial for looking down and in; its paralysis leads to a characteristic vertical diplopia and a compensatory head tilt.

content.definition: Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the degeneration of anterior horn cells (lower motor neurons) in the spinal cord, leading to progressive muscle weakness and atrophy. It is caused by a deficiency of the [[6a781682|Survival Motor Neuron (SMN) protein]].
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal recessive deletion or mutation of the SMN1 gene. Disease severity is inversely correlated with the number of copies of a second gene, SMN2.
  • Pathophysiology: Deficiency of the SMN protein, which is critical for snRNP assembly and pre-mRNA splicing, leads to apoptosis of lower motor neurons.
  • Clinical Presentation: Pure lower motor neuron signs. Presents with symmetric, progressive muscle weakness (proximal > distal) and atrophy, hypotonia, and absent deep tendon reflexes. Sensation and cognition are intact.
  • Types: Classified by age of onset and severity. Type 1 ([[17c628e2|Werdnig-Hoffmann disease]]) is the most severe, with onset in infancy and death from respiratory failure by age 2 if untreated.
  • USMLE Tip: The classic presentation of SMA Type 1 is a 'floppy baby' with symmetric weakness, tongue fasciculations, and areflexia. The underlying defect is in pre-mRNA splicing.
content.takeAway: Spinal Muscular Atrophy is a devastating lower motor neuron disease caused by a genetic defect in the SMN protein, essential for neuronal survival, leading to progressive, symmetric muscle wasting and weakness that is most severe in infants.

content.definition: Spinal nerves are 31 pairs of mixed nerves that emerge from the spinal cord and are a fundamental part of the peripheral nervous system. Each nerve is formed by the union of a dorsal (sensory) root and a ventral (motor) root.
content.atAGlance:
• Composition: 31 pairs: 8 cervical (C1-C8), 12 thoracic (T1-T12), 5 lumbar (L1-L5), 5 sacral (S1-S5), and 1 coccygeal.
  • Exit from Vertebral Canal: C1-C7 nerves exit above their corresponding vertebra. The C8 nerve exits between C7 and T1. All subsequent nerves (T1 and below) exit below their corresponding vertebra.
  • Function: They carry motor, sensory, and autonomic signals between the spinal cord and the body.
  • Dermatomes and Myotomes: Each spinal nerve innervates a specific area of skin (dermatome) and a specific group of muscles (myotome).
  • Lower Extent of Spinal Cord: In adults, the spinal cord ends at the L1-L2 vertebral level (conus medullaris). The nerve roots below this level form the [[1c4d7e8f|cauda equina]].
  • USMLE Tip: Knowing the vertebral exit pattern is important for localizing nerve root compression. For example, a herniated disc between L4 and L5 will typically compress the L5 nerve root.
content.takeAway: Spinal nerves are the vital conduits connecting the spinal cord to the periphery, with each of the 31 pairs carrying a mix of motor and sensory fibers to a specific segment of the body, forming the basis of the dermatomal and myotomal maps.

content.definition: Spinal reflexes are involuntary and nearly instantaneous movements that are mediated by a reflex arc at the level of the spinal cord, without requiring input from the brain. Testing these reflexes is a fundamental part of the neurological examination.
content.atAGlance:
• Reflex Arc Components: A sensory receptor, an afferent neuron, an integration center (spinal cord), an efferent neuron, and an effector (muscle).
  • Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): Monosynaptic stretch reflexes that test the integrity of specific spinal nerve roots.
    - [[87d19a70|Achilles]]: S1, S2
    - Patellar: L2, L3, L4
    - [[f36cfe18|Biceps]] & [[ac55d026|Brachioradialis]]: C5, C6
    - [[b79b3546|Triceps]]: C7, C8
  • Superficial Reflexes: Polysynaptic reflexes.
    - [[ce2052d6|Anal wink]]: S3, S4
    - [[cd09cad7|Cremasteric]]: L1, L2
  • Interpretation:
    - Hyporeflexia/Areflexia (Diminished/Absent): Suggests a lower motor neuron lesion (e.g., nerve root compression, peripheral neuropathy).
    - Hyperreflexia (Exaggerated): Suggests an upper motor neuron lesion (e.g., stroke, spinal cord injury).
  • USMLE Tip: The state of the spinal reflexes is a key differentiator between UMN and LMN lesions.
content.takeAway: Spinal reflexes are the spinal cord's automatic responses to sensory stimuli, providing a rapid and reliable clinical tool to assess the integrity of specific nerve roots and to distinguish between upper and lower motor neuron pathologies.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Stimulus] --> B(Sensory Receptor); B --> C(Afferent Neuron); C --> D(Spinal Cord); D --> E(Efferent Neuron); E --> F(Effector Muscle); F --> G(Response);

content.definition: Spinal tracts are bundles of myelinated nerve fibers (white matter) that run up and down the spinal cord, carrying information between the brain and the periphery. They are functionally segregated into ascending (sensory) and descending (motor) pathways.
content.atAGlance:
• Ascending (Sensory) Tracts:
    - [[e7f5cbbe|Dorsal Columns]]: Carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception. Ascend ipsilaterally and decussate in the medulla.
    - [[07eecef1|Spinothalamic Tract]]: Carries pain, temperature, and crude touch. Decussates at the level of the spinal cord in the anterior white commissure and ascends contralaterally.
    - [[5468da40|Spinocerebellar Tracts]]: Carry unconscious proprioceptive information to the cerebellum.
  • Descending (Motor) Tracts:
    - [[fb0a5fdc|Corticospinal Tract]]: The primary pathway for voluntary motor control. Descends from the motor cortex and decussates in the medullary pyramids to control the contralateral body.
  • Clinical Localization: The distinct pathways and decussation points of these tracts are crucial for localizing spinal cord lesions. For example, [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]] (hemisection) causes a characteristic pattern of ipsilateral and contralateral deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: Master the three major tracts: Dorsal Columns, Spinothalamic, and Corticospinal. Know what they carry, where they are located in the cord, and where they decussate.
content.takeAway: The spinal tracts are the information superhighways of the spinal cord, with anatomically and functionally distinct ascending and descending lanes that allow for precise clinical localization of lesions based on the pattern of sensory and motor deficits.

content.definition: The spinocerebellar tracts are ascending sensory pathways that transmit unconscious proprioceptive information from the muscles and joints to the cerebellum. This information is crucial for the cerebellum's role in coordinating movement and maintaining balance.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Carry unconscious proprioception (information about muscle stretch and tension) to the cerebellum.
  • Major Tracts: Includes the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, ventral spinocerebellar tract, and others.
  • Pathway: These tracts are primarily ipsilateral. Information from one side of the body is transmitted to the ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere.
  • Clinical Significance: Damage to the spinocerebellar tracts contributes to the [[9767fd6b|ataxia]] seen in certain neurological disorders.
  • Associated Diseases: These tracts are notably affected in [[39bc1763|Friedreich ataxia]], a hereditary ataxia where their degeneration contributes to the characteristic gait and limb ataxia.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the spinocerebellar tracts (unconscious proprioception to the cerebellum) from the dorsal columns (conscious proprioception to the cerebral cortex).
content.takeAway: The spinocerebellar tracts are the cerebellum's private lines of communication with the body, providing a continuous, unconscious stream of proprioceptive data that is essential for real-time motor coordination and balance.

content.definition: The Spinothalamic Tract (also known as the anterolateral system) is a major ascending sensory pathway that transmits information about pain, temperature, and crude touch from the body to the thalamus.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Transmits nociceptive, thermal, and non-discriminative tactile information.
  • Pathway: A three-neuron chain:
    1. First-order neuron: From peripheral receptors to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord, where it synapses.
    2. Second-order neuron: Decussates (crosses) at the level of the spinal cord in the anterior white commissure, then ascends in the contralateral anterolateral funiculus.
    3. Third-order neuron: From the VPL nucleus of the thalamus to the primary somatosensory cortex.
  • Somatotopy: The tract is organized somatotopically, with fibers from the sacral levels located most laterally and cervical fibers most medially.
  • Lesions: A lesion of the spinothalamic tract causes contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning 1-2 segments below the level of the lesion.
  • Associated Syndromes: Damaged in [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]] (contralateral loss), [[b48b54d7|anterior spinal artery occlusion]] (bilateral loss), and [[d2b8e10c|syringomyelia]] (bilateral loss at the level of the syrinx).
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature is its decussation at the spinal cord level. This contrasts with the dorsal columns, which decussate in the medulla.
content.takeAway: The Spinothalamic Tract is the essential pathway for pain and temperature sensation, characterized by its immediate decussation in the spinal cord, which results in contralateral sensory loss when the tract is damaged.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Receptor] --> B(1st Order Neuron); B --> C(Synapse in Dorsal Horn); C --Decussation--> D(2nd Order Neuron); D --> E(Ascends Contralaterally); E --> F(Synapse in Thalamus); F --> G(3rd Order Neuron); G --> H(Somatosensory Cortex);

content.definition: Spongiform cortex, or spongiform encephalopathy, is the pathognomonic histological finding in prion diseases, such as [[86fe59ba|Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)]]. It is characterized by the presence of numerous microscopic vacuoles in the neuropil of the cerebral cortex, giving it a sponge-like appearance.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: On H&E stain, the gray matter shows diffuse, small, empty-looking vacuoles in the neuropil, which can coalesce into larger cysts.
  • Pathophysiology: The vacuoles are the result of extensive neuronal loss, astrogliosis, and the accumulation of abnormal, protease-resistant prion protein (PrPSc) aggregates.
  • Key Feature: This vacuolation occurs without a significant inflammatory infiltrate, which is a key feature distinguishing prion diseases from viral encephalitis.
  • Associated Disease: The hallmark of all prion diseases, including [[86fe59ba|CJD]], kuru, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy ('mad cow disease').
  • USMLE Tip: The term 'spongiform encephalopathy' is synonymous with prion disease. A brain biopsy showing vacuolation without inflammation is diagnostic.
content.takeAway: The spongiform cortex is the devastating microscopic endpoint of prion disease, where the accumulation of misfolded proteins leads to widespread neuronal death, leaving behind a brain riddled with empty vacuoles, resembling a sponge.

content.definition: The stapes is the smallest of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear. It is also the smallest bone in the human body. Its function is to transmit sound vibrations from the incus to the oval window of the inner ear.
content.atAGlance:
• Anatomy: Shaped like a stirrup (Latin: stapes). It consists of a head (which articulates with the incus), two crura (limbs), and a footplate (which fits into the oval window).
  • Function: As the final bone in the ossicular chain, it acts like a piston, pushing on the oval window to create pressure waves in the fluid of the [[001c359f|cochlea]].
  • Stapedius Muscle: The stapes is attached to the stapedius muscle, which is innervated by the [[dea9755f|facial nerve (CN VII)]]. This muscle contracts in response to loud noises (acoustic reflex), stiffening the ossicular chain to protect the inner ear.
  • Pathology:
    - Otosclerosis: A condition where abnormal bone growth fixes the stapes footplate to the oval window, preventing it from vibrating. This is a common cause of progressive [[2b500647|conductive hearing loss]].
    - Facial Nerve Palsy: Paralysis of the stapedius muscle can cause hyperacusis (sensitivity to loud sounds).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the stapes as the final link in the mechanical amplification of sound in the middle ear. Its fixation in otosclerosis is a classic cause of conductive hearing loss.
content.takeAway: The stapes is the tiny, piston-like bone that bridges the middle and inner ear, converting the amplified vibrations of the ossicles into the hydraulic waves within the cochlea that are necessary for hearing.

content.definition: Startle myoclonus is a type of myoclonus (sudden, brief, shock-like muscle jerks) that is elicited by an unexpected sensory stimulus, such as a loud noise, a sudden touch, or a bright light.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: An exaggerated, involuntary jerking response to a surprising stimulus.
  • Classic Association: It is a characteristic and highly suggestive feature of [[86fe59ba|Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)]], a rapidly progressive prion disease.
  • Other Causes: Can also be seen in other encephalopathies, such as anoxic brain injury, and in certain genetic epilepsy syndromes.
  • Clinical Significance: In the context of a rapidly progressive dementia, the presence of startle myoclonus is a strong clinical clue that points toward a diagnosis of CJD.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with rapidly progressing dementia who exhibits sudden, violent jerks in response to the examiner clapping their hands has startle myoclonus, a classic sign of CJD.
content.takeAway: Startle myoclonus is an exaggerated, reflexive jerk to a surprise stimulus, which, when seen in a patient with rapid cognitive decline, is a near-pathognomonic sign of the profound cortical and subcortical irritability caused by Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

content.definition: Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as a single continuous epileptic seizure lasting longer than 5 minutes, or two or more seizures occurring without a complete recovery of consciousness in between.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A failure of the mechanisms that normally terminate a seizure, leading to a state of prolonged, self-sustaining neuronal firing. This can cause excitotoxic neuronal injury, metabolic derangements, and cardiorespiratory compromise.
  • Types: Can be convulsive (e.g., continuous tonic-clonic seizures) or non-convulsive (e.g., continuous absence or focal impaired awareness seizures). Convulsive status epilepticus is the most life-threatening.
  • Management: This is a medical emergency requiring rapid intervention to stop the seizure and prevent brain damage.
    1. Initial Therapy (0-5 min): Stabilize the patient (Airway, Breathing, Circulation).
    2. First-line Therapy (5-20 min): IV [[14464617|benzodiazepines]] (e.g., lorazepam, [[e14063c3|diazepam]]).
    3. Second-line Therapy (20-40 min): IV anticonvulsants like fosphenytoin, [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], [[0d37e045|valproic acid]], or [[2341f9c0|levetiracetam]].
  • USMLE Tip: The first-line drug for terminating status epilepticus is an IV benzodiazepine. Remember the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are always the first step in any emergency.
content.takeAway: Status epilepticus is a brain 'stuck in a seizure,' a dangerous state of unrelenting neuronal firing that requires immediate treatment with IV benzodiazepines to prevent permanent neurological damage and systemic complications.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Seizure > 5 min] --> B(Status Epilepticus); B --> C(Administer IV Benzodiazepine); C --Failure--> D(Administer IV Anticonvulsant);

content.definition: Steroids (specifically, glucocorticoids like prednisone or methylprednisolone) are potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive agents used in neurology to treat a variety of inflammatory and autoimmune conditions of the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Broad anti-inflammatory effects, including inhibiting phospholipase A2, suppressing the transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines, and inducing apoptosis in lymphocytes.
  • Use in Multiple Sclerosis: High-dose IV steroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are the first-line treatment for acute relapses of [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]]. They shorten the duration and severity of the relapse but do not affect the long-term course of the disease.
  • Use in Vasogenic Edema: Dexamethasone is used to reduce vasogenic edema associated with brain tumors and abscesses by stabilizing the blood-brain barrier.
  • Other Uses: Used in other autoimmune neurological conditions like myasthenia gravis crisis and inflammatory myopathies.
  • Adverse Effects: Long-term use can cause Cushing's syndrome, osteoporosis, hyperglycemia, and immunosuppression. Acute high-dose therapy can cause psychosis ('steroid psychosis'), insomnia, and hyperglycemia.
  • USMLE Tip: For an acute MS flare, the answer is high-dose steroids. For long-term disease modification in MS, other agents like interferon-β or glatiramer are used.
content.takeAway: In neurology, high-dose steroids act as a powerful 'fire extinguisher' for acute inflammatory events, most notably for shortening the duration of a multiple sclerosis relapse by rapidly suppressing the autoimmune attack on myelin.

content.definition: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) is a severe, immune-mediated mucocutaneous reaction, most often triggered by medications. It is characterized by extensive necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. It is considered a less severe form of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN), with SJS involving <10% of the body surface area.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction where drug-specific cytotoxic T cells and NK cells induce widespread apoptosis of keratinocytes.
  • Clinical Presentation: Begins with a prodrome of fever and flu-like symptoms, followed by the abrupt onset of an erythematous, morbilliform rash and mucosal lesions. The rash progresses to form bullae and sloughing of the skin. Mucosal involvement (oral, ocular, genital) is a hallmark.
  • Causative Drugs: The most commonly implicated drugs are anticonvulsants (especially [[08d19a8f|lamotrigine]], [[eddd2bc5|carbamazepine]], [[5aea213f|phenytoin]]), allopurinol, and sulfonamides.
  • Nikolsky's Sign: A positive Nikolsky's sign (slight rubbing of the skin results in exfoliation) is often present.
  • Management: This is a medical emergency requiring immediate withdrawal of the offending drug and supportive care in a burn unit.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient who recently started a new drug (especially an anticonvulsant or allopurinol) and develops a fever, rash, and painful mucosal erosions has SJS until proven otherwise.
content.takeAway: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome is a catastrophic drug-induced hypersensitivity reaction where the immune system attacks the skin and mucous membranes, causing them to blister and peel off as if the patient has been severely burned.

content.definition: Strabismus is a condition in which the eyes do not properly align with each other when looking at an object. This misalignment can be constant or intermittent.
content.atAGlance:
• Terminology:
    - Esotropia: Inward turning of the eye.
    - Exotropia: Outward turning of the eye.
    - Hypertropia: Upward deviation of the eye.
    - Hypotropia: Downward deviation of the eye.
  • Causes: Can be due to extraocular muscle weakness, refractive error (accommodative esotropia), or a problem with the innervating cranial nerves (paralytic strabismus, e.g., [[01c1b782|CN VI palsy]] causing esotropia).
  • Complications in Children: If not corrected during the critical period of visual development, the brain may suppress the image from the deviating eye to avoid [[9914d433|diplopia]]. This can lead to the development of [[a4a401c7|amblyopia]] ('lazy eye'), a permanent reduction in visual acuity in that eye.
  • Diagnosis: The cover-uncover test is used to detect strabismus.
  • Leukocoria: The presence of a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) in a child with strabismus is a red flag for [[63b964af|retinoblastoma]].
  • USMLE Tip: The primary concern with strabismus in a child is the risk of developing amblyopia. Early detection and treatment (e.g., glasses, patching, surgery) are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss.
content.takeAway: Strabismus is a misalignment of the eyes that, in children, poses a significant threat to vision development by potentially leading to amblyopia if the brain learns to ignore the input from the deviating eye.

content.definition: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is a gram-positive, lancet-shaped diplococcus that is a major cause of community-acquired pneumonia, meningitis, otitis media, and sinusitis.
content.atAGlance:
• Microbiology: Gram-positive, α-hemolytic, lancet-shaped diplococcus. It is catalase-negative and optochin-sensitive.
  • Virulence Factor: Its most important virulence factor is its polysaccharide capsule, which is antiphagocytic.
  • Diseases (Meningitis): The most common cause of bacterial meningitis in adults, children, and the elderly (excluding neonates).
  • Diseases (Other): The most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (lobar pneumonia with 'rusty' sputum), [[a03641af|otitis media]] in children, and sinusitis.
  • Risk Factors for Invasive Disease: Patients who are asplenic (e.g., sickle cell disease, splenectomy) are at high risk for overwhelming sepsis because the spleen is critical for clearing encapsulated organisms.
  • Prevention: Vaccination with pneumococcal conjugate (PCV) and polysaccharide (PPSV) vaccines is highly effective.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember S. pneumoniae as the #1 cause of MOPS: Meningitis, Otitis media, Pneumonia, and Sinusitis.
content.takeAway: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a formidable encapsulated bacterium that is the leading cause of several common and serious respiratory tract and CNS infections, with its polysaccharide capsule being the key to both its virulence and the target of effective vaccines.

content.definition: Stretch receptors are a type of mechanoreceptor that respond to the stretching of the tissue in which they are located. They are crucial for proprioception and the regulation of various physiological processes.
content.atAGlance:
• Muscle Spindles: Located within skeletal muscles, they are stretch receptors that detect changes in muscle length. They are the sensory component of the deep tendon reflex (e.g., patellar reflex).
  • Golgi Tendon Organs (GTOs): Located in tendons, they detect changes in muscle tension. They have an inhibitory function to protect muscles from excessive force.
  • Baroreceptors: Stretch receptors located in the walls of the carotid sinus and aortic arch. They detect changes in blood pressure by sensing the stretch of the arterial wall.
  • Pulmonary Stretch Receptors: Located in the smooth muscle of the airways, they are involved in the Hering-Breuer reflex, which terminates inhalation to prevent over-inflation of the lungs.
  • USMLE Tip: The muscle spindle is the key receptor for the monosynaptic deep tendon reflex, a fundamental component of the neurological exam.
content.takeAway: Stretch receptors are the body's internal strain gauges, providing the central nervous system with continuous feedback on the state of muscles, tendons, and blood vessels, which is essential for motor control and autonomic regulation.

content.definition: Sleep is a naturally recurring state of mind and body, characterized by altered consciousness, relatively inhibited sensory activity, reduced muscle activity, and inhibition of nearly all voluntary muscles during REM sleep. It is divided into distinct stages that cycle throughout the night.
content.atAGlance:
• Sleep Architecture: The cyclical pattern of sleep stages over the course of a night. A normal adult cycles through the stages approximately every 90 minutes.
  • Non-REM (NREM) Sleep: Divided into three stages (N1, N2, N3).
    - N1: Light sleep.
    - N2: Deeper sleep, characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on EEG.
    - N3: Deepest, slow-wave sleep. Important for physical restoration. Sleepwalking, night terrors, and bedwetting occur during N3.
  • REM Sleep: Characterized by rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, and dreaming. EEG resembles the awake state ('paradoxical sleep'). Important for memory consolidation.
  • Physiology: The sleep-wake cycle is regulated by the [[ad2b0b65|suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN)]] of the hypothalamus, which controls the release of melatonin. Growth hormone is primarily released during N3 sleep.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the EEG waveforms for each stage: N2 (sleep spindles, K-complexes), N3 (delta waves), REM (beta waves, looks like awake EEG). Remember that benzodiazepines and alcohol suppress REM and N3 sleep.
content.takeAway: Sleep is an active and highly structured physiological process, cycling through distinct NREM and REM stages, each with unique neural activity and functions, from physical repair in deep NREM sleep to memory consolidation during REM sleep.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Awake] --> B(NREM Stage 1); B --> C(NREM Stage 2); C --> D(NREM Stage 3); D --> C; C --> E(REM Sleep); E --> A;

content.definition: A mutation in the Survival Motor Neuron 1 (SMN1) gene is the genetic cause of [[e6820b7f|spinal muscular atrophy (SMA)]], an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the degeneration of lower motor neurons.
content.atAGlance:
• Gene Function: The SMN1 gene produces the full-length, functional [[6a781682|SMN protein]], which is critical for the assembly of spliceosomes and proper pre-mRNA splicing.
  • Mutation Type: In >95% of SMA cases, there is a homozygous deletion of the SMN1 gene.
  • Pathophysiology: Loss of the SMN1 gene leads to a profound deficiency of SMN protein, causing apoptosis of anterior horn cells (lower motor neurons) in the spinal cord.
  • Role of SMN2: Humans have a nearly identical gene, SMN2, which can also produce SMN protein. However, due to a single nucleotide difference, SMN2 is inefficiently spliced and produces mostly a truncated, non-functional protein. The number of SMN2 copies a person has determines the severity of SMA, as more copies can partially compensate for the lack of SMN1.
  • USMLE Tip: SMA is a disease of defective pre-mRNA splicing caused by an SMN1 mutation. The number of SMN2 copies acts as a disease modifier.
content.takeAway: A homozygous SMN1 gene mutation is the root cause of spinal muscular atrophy, leading to a deficiency in a protein essential for RNA splicing and the subsequent death of lower motor neurons, with the disease's severity being modulated by the number of 'backup' SMN2 gene copies.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[SMN1 Gene Deletion] --> B(No functional SMN protein from SMN1); C[SMN2 Gene] --> D(Small amount of functional SMN protein); B & D --> E(Overall SMN Protein Deficiency); E --> F(Lower Motor Neuron Death); F --> G(Spinal Muscular Atrophy);

content.definition: The substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) is a nucleus in the midbrain that is a key component of the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]]. It is composed of dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum, forming the nigrostriatal pathway.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Part of the substantia nigra in the midbrain. Its neurons contain neuromelanin, giving it a dark appearance on gross section.
  • Function: The SNc provides [[90adc821|dopamine]] to the striatum (caudate and putamen). This dopaminergic input modulates the activity of the direct and indirect pathways of the basal ganglia to facilitate the initiation of voluntary movement.
  • Receptor Effects: Dopamine from the SNc excites the direct pathway via D1 receptors and inhibits the indirect pathway via D2 receptors. The net effect is to facilitate movement.
  • Pathology: The hallmark of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] is the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the SNc. This leads to a dopamine deficit in the striatum, causing the characteristic motor symptoms of bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor.
  • Histology in Parkinson's: Surviving neurons in the SNc of Parkinson's patients often contain eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions called Lewy bodies.
  • USMLE Tip: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta is the fundamental pathology of Parkinson disease.
content.takeAway: The substantia nigra pars compacta is the dopamine-producing powerhouse of the motor system; its degeneration in Parkinson's disease starves the basal ganglia of dopamine, leading to a profound impairment in the ability to initiate and control movement.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[SNc] --Dopamine--> B(Striatum); B --> C(Modulation of Direct/Indirect Pathways); C --> D(Facilitation of Movement); A --x Degeneration in Parkinson's Disease;

content.definition: Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) are a class of antidepressant medications that work by blocking the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine. They are used to treat depression, anxiety disorders, and neuropathic pain.
content.atAGlance:
• Agents: Venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, levomilnacipran.
  • Mechanism of Action: Inhibit the serotonin transporter (SERT) and the norepinephrine transporter (NET), increasing the synaptic levels of both neurotransmitters.
  • Clinical Use:
    - Major depressive disorder.
    - [[d1c786e9|Anxiety disorders]] (e.g., GAD, panic disorder).
    - Neuropathic pain (e.g., diabetic neuropathy) and fibromyalgia (especially duloxetine).
  • Adverse Effects: Similar to SSRIs (e.g., nausea, sexual dysfunction). The norepinephrine effects can cause increased blood pressure and heart rate, which should be monitored.
  • snRNP Assembly: This is a function of the [[6a781682|SMN protein]] and is not related to SNRIs. The index entry is likely a processing error.
  • USMLE Tip: SNRIs are a good choice for patients with depression and comorbid neuropathic pain or fibromyalgia. Duloxetine is specifically approved for these pain indications.
content.takeAway: SNRIs are dual-action antidepressants that boost both serotonin and norepinephrine, making them effective not only for depression but also for treating chronic pain syndromes by modulating descending pain pathways.

content.definition: Mutations in the SOD1 (superoxide dismutase 1) gene are the most common known cause of familial [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]], accounting for about 20% of familial cases.
content.atAGlance:
• Gene Product: The SOD1 gene encodes the enzyme copper-zinc superoxide dismutase, which is a ubiquitous antioxidant enzyme that catalyzes the dismutation of superoxide radicals into oxygen and hydrogen peroxide.
  • Pathophysiology: The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is believed to be a toxic gain-of-function mutation rather than a loss of enzymatic activity. The mutant SOD1 protein is prone to misfolding and aggregation, which may be toxic to motor neurons through various mechanisms, including oxidative stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and excitotoxicity.
  • Inheritance: Familial ALS due to SOD1 mutations is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
  • Clinical Relevance: While only a small fraction of all ALS cases are familial, the discovery of SOD1 mutations provided a crucial first insight into the molecular pathogenesis of the disease.
  • USMLE Tip: Associate SOD1 mutations with familial ALS. The mechanism is thought to be a toxic gain-of-function, not a simple loss of antioxidant capacity.
content.takeAway: SOD1 mutations are a key genetic cause of familial ALS, where a toxic gain-of-function in this antioxidant enzyme leads to the selective death of motor neurons, highlighting the role of protein misfolding and oxidative stress in the disease.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[SOD1 Mutation] --> B(Misfolded SOD1 Protein); B --> C(Toxic Gain-of-Function); C --> D(Oxidative Stress & Aggregation); D --> E(Motor Neuron Death); E --> F(Familial ALS);

content.definition: The primary somatosensory cortex (S1) is the main cortical area for processing tactile information from the body. It is located in the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe (Brodmann areas 1, 2, and 3).
  • Function: Receives and processes sensory information from the contralateral side of the body, including touch, pressure, pain, temperature, vibration, and proprioception.
  • Input: Receives its primary input from the ventral posterior nucleus (VPN) of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], which is composed of the [[2ae957b8|VPL]] (for the body) and [[23ac314a|VPM]] (for the face) nuclei.
  • Somatotopic Organization (Sensory Homunculus): The cortex is organized somatotopically, with different body parts represented in specific areas. The face and hands have a disproportionately large representation due to their high sensory acuity.
  • Lesions: A lesion in the primary somatosensory cortex causes contralateral sensory loss (e.g., numbness, paresthesias).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the location (postcentral gyrus) and the somatotopic organization (homunculus), with the leg represented medially (supplied by ACA) and the arm/face represented laterally (supplied by MCA).
content.takeAway: The somatosensory cortex is the brain's primary 'touch map,' a highly organized region in the parietal lobe that receives all tactile information from the thalamus and translates it into our conscious perception of sensation from the contralateral body.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Thalamus - VPL/VPM] --> B(Primary Somatosensory Cortex); B --> C(Conscious Perception of Sensation);

content.definition: The Sonic hedgehog (SHH) signaling pathway is a crucial signaling pathway in embryonic development, particularly for patterning the central nervous system. The SHH protein is a signaling molecule (morphogen) that acts in a concentration-dependent manner.
content.atAGlance:
• Function in Neurodevelopment: Secreted by the underlying notochord, SHH acts as a ventralizing signal for the neural tube.
  • Ventralization: High concentrations of SHH induce the formation of the [[253e3efb|basal plate]], which gives rise to motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord and motor nuclei of the brainstem.
  • Counterpart Signal: The dorsalizing signal is [[869535a9|Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP)]], which is secreted by the ectoderm and induces the formation of the [[43be7a6e|alar plate]] (sensory neurons).
  • Holoprosencephaly: Mutations in the SHH pathway are a cause of holoprosencephaly, a severe birth defect where the forebrain fails to divide into two hemispheres.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the source and effect: SHH from the notochord (floor) induces the ventral/motor basal plate. BMP from the ectoderm (roof) induces the dorsal/sensory alar plate.
content.takeAway: Sonic hedgehog is the key 'ventralizing' morphogen in the developing nervous system, secreted from the notochord to instruct the ventral neural tube to become the motor [[253e3efb|basal plate]], thereby establishing the fundamental motor-sensory axis of the CNS.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Notochord] --Secretes--> B(SHH); B --Induces--> C(Ventral Neural Tube); C --> D(Basal Plate); D --> E(Motor Neurons);

content.definition: Spasmolytics, or skeletal muscle relaxants, are a group of drugs used to alleviate symptoms associated with muscle spasticity or acute muscle spasms by acting either on the central nervous system or directly on the muscle.
content.atAGlance:
• Baclofen: A GABAB receptor agonist that acts on the spinal cord to suppress hyperactive reflexes. Used for spasticity in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] and spinal cord injury.
  • Cyclobenzaprine: A centrally acting muscle relaxant, structurally related to TCAs. Used for acute muscle spasms from musculoskeletal conditions. Has significant anticholinergic side effects and causes sedation.
  • Tizanidine: A centrally acting α2-adrenergic agonist that inhibits motor neuron activity. Used for spasticity.
  • Dantrolene: Acts directly on skeletal muscle by blocking Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (inhibits ryanodine receptor). Used to treat malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the uses: [[1ddc3f08|baclofen]] and tizanidine for chronic spasticity (MS, spinal cord injury), cyclobenzaprine for acute muscle strain, and [[d67a204d|dantrolene]] for life-threatening hyperthermic syndromes.
content.takeAway: Spasmolytics reduce muscle hyperactivity through diverse mechanisms, ranging from central GABAergic and adrenergic modulation (baclofen, tizanidine) to direct interference with muscle contraction machinery (dantrolene), the latter being crucial for treating hyperthermic emergencies.

content.definition: Spastic paresis is a form of muscle weakness (paresis) combined with spasticity (increased muscle tone). It is a hallmark sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Results from damage to the descending corticospinal tracts, which leads to a loss of inhibitory modulation on spinal reflex arcs. This results in hypertonia and hyperreflexia.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients have weakness, but their muscles are stiff and resistant to passive movement (spasticity). Deep tendon reflexes are exaggerated, and a positive [[8947da55|Babinski sign]] is present.
  • Gait: A spastic gait is often seen, where the legs are stiff and the feet are dragged or circumducted.
  • Causes: Any UMN lesion can cause spastic paresis, including [[c5da3c57|stroke]], spinal cord injury, [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]].
  • USMLE Tip: Spastic paresis is a key component of the UMN syndrome. Contrast it with the flaccid paralysis seen in LMN lesions.
content.takeAway: Spastic paresis is a paradoxical state of weakness combined with stiffness, resulting from an upper motor neuron lesion that removes the brain's inhibitory control over spinal reflexes, leading to hyperactive and poorly controlled muscle tone.

content.definition: Spasticity is a motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in muscle tone (hypertonia) and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia). It is a component of the upper motor neuron (UMN) syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by damage to the descending motor pathways (e.g., corticospinal tract) that provide inhibitory input to spinal motor neurons. The loss of this inhibition leads to hyperexcitability of the stretch reflex arc.
  • Clinical Signs: Increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, clonus, and a positive [[8947da55|Babinski sign]]. A specific type of spasticity is [[ca51f29a|clasp-knife spasticity]].
  • Associated Conditions: Seen in UMN lesions such as [[c5da3c57|stroke]], spinal cord injury, [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]], and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]].
  • Treatment: Can be managed with physical therapy and spasmolytic medications like [[1ddc3f08|baclofen]], tizanidine, or [[14464617|benzodiazepines]].
  • USMLE Tip: Spasticity is a key sign that localizes a lesion to the upper motor neuron.
content.takeAway: Spasticity is a state of muscular hypertonia resulting from the disinhibition of spinal reflexes after an upper motor neuron injury, leading to stiff, overactive muscles.

content.definition: The special senses are the senses that have specialized organs devoted to them. They include vision, hearing (audition), balance (equilibrium), taste (gustation), and smell (olfaction).
content.atAGlance:
• Vision: Detected by photoreceptors in the retina; transmitted by the optic nerve (CN II).
  • Hearing & Balance: Detected by hair cells in the [[001c359f|cochlea]] and vestibular apparatus, respectively; transmitted by the [[6fded3e7|vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII)]]. The field of study is [[c5a1d2fc|otology]].
  • Taste: Detected by taste buds; transmitted by CN VII, IX, and X.
  • Smell: Detected by olfactory receptors in the nasal epithelium; transmitted by the olfactory nerve (CN I). It is the only sense that does not relay through the thalamus.
  • General Senses: This contrasts with the general senses (somatic senses), which include touch, temperature, pain, and proprioception, whose receptors are distributed throughout the body.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the cranial nerves associated with each special sense.
content.takeAway: The special senses are our sophisticated sensory systems for perceiving the external world, each with a dedicated organ and a specific cranial nerve pathway to the brain.

content.definition: Spina bifida occulta is the mildest and most common form of spina bifida, a type of neural tube defect. It is characterized by a failure of the vertebral arches to fuse, typically in the lumbosacral region, without herniation of the spinal cord or meninges.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: A failure of the caudal neuropore to close completely, resulting in a bony defect of the vertebral arch. The spinal cord and meninges remain in their normal position.
  • Clinical Presentation: It is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on imaging. The term 'occulta' means hidden.
  • Cutaneous Signs: The site of the bony defect may be marked by a patch of hair, a dimple, a birthmark, or a lipoma on the overlying skin.
  • Neurological Deficits: Usually, there are no neurological deficits. Rarely, it can be associated with a tethered cord syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: A tuft of hair or a dimple over the lower back in an otherwise asymptomatic infant is the classic presentation of spina bifida occulta.
content.takeAway: Spina bifida occulta is a 'hidden' neural tube defect where the only sign of the underlying vertebral anomaly is often a small patch of hair or a dimple on the lower back, with the spinal cord itself being unaffected.

content.definition: The spinal cord is a long, thin, tubular structure made up of nervous tissue, which extends from the medulla oblongata in the brainstem to the lumbar region of the vertebral column. It is the main pathway for information connecting the brain and peripheral nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Composed of central gray matter (containing neuron cell bodies) surrounded by outer white matter (containing myelinated axon tracts).
  • Lower Extent: In adults, the spinal cord terminates at the L1-L2 vertebral level as the conus medullaris. The nerve roots below this form the [[1c4d7e8f|cauda equina]].
  • Spinal Tracts: Contains major ascending (sensory) and descending (motor) tracts, including the [[fb0a5fdc|corticospinal tracts]], [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]], and [[07eecef1|spinothalamic tracts]].
  • Spinal Reflexes: Mediates reflexes independently of the brain via reflex arcs.
  • Lesions/Syndromes: Damage to the spinal cord results in specific syndromes based on the location and extent of the lesion (e.g., [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard syndrome]], [[b48b54d7|anterior spinal artery syndrome]], [[d2b8e10c|syringomyelia]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Understanding the cross-sectional anatomy of the spinal cord, including the location of the major tracts and their decussation points, is essential for localizing lesions.
content.takeAway: The spinal cord is the critical information highway of the body, containing precisely organized tracts that carry motor commands down from the brain and sensory information up to it, while also managing local reflexes independently.

content.definition: Spinal cord lesions/syndromes are distinct patterns of neurological deficits that result from damage to specific areas or tracts within the spinal cord. The clinical presentation allows for precise anatomical localization of the lesion.
content.atAGlance:
• [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard Syndrome]]: Hemisection of the cord. Ipsilateral UMN signs and loss of proprioception/vibration below the lesion; contralateral loss of pain/temperature below the lesion.
  • [[b48b54d7|Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome]]: Infarct of the anterior 2/3 of the cord. Bilateral loss of motor function and pain/temperature below the lesion, with spared dorsal columns (proprioception/vibration).
  • [[d2b8e10c|Syringomyelia]]: Cystic lesion of the central canal. Causes a bilateral, 'cape-like' loss of pain and temperature in the upper extremities (damage to anterior white commissure).
  • [[6f5bea90|Subacute Combined Degeneration]]: Due to B12 deficiency. Demyelination of dorsal columns, lateral corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts.
  • [[71daebd6|Tabes Dorsalis]]: Tertiary syphilis. Degeneration of dorsal columns and dorsal roots.
  • [[45dd6d19|Multiple Sclerosis]]: Can cause random, asymmetric demyelinating plaques anywhere in the spinal cord white matter.
  • USMLE Tip: These syndromes are a classic test of your knowledge of spinal cord tract anatomy and function. Draw out the cross-section and trace the pathways to solve problems.
content.takeAway: The predictable organization of the spinal cord's tracts means that specific patterns of injury, or spinal cord syndromes, produce highly characteristic and localizable clinical deficits, making them a favorite topic for testing neuroanatomical knowledge.

content.definition: Spinal dysraphism refers to a group of congenital malformations of the spinal cord and vertebral column resulting from the incomplete closure of the neural tube during embryonic development (neurulation). These are also known as neural tube defects of the spine.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Failure of the caudal (posterior) neuropore to close during the 4th week of gestation. Associated with maternal folate deficiency.
  • Types:
    - [[63014ebc|Spina Bifida Occulta]]: Mildest form. Failure of vertebral arch fusion, with no herniation of neural tissue. Often asymptomatic, may have an overlying skin dimple or tuft of hair.
    - Meningocele: Herniation of the meninges (but not the spinal cord) through the bony defect, forming a CSF-filled sac.
    - Myelomeningocele: Most severe form. Herniation of both the meninges and the spinal cord through the defect. Almost always associated with neurological deficits below the level of the lesion and a [[b96a6a07|Chiari II malformation]].
  • Diagnosis: Detected prenatally by elevated maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and ultrasound.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the types based on what is herniating: Occulta = nothing, Meningocele = meninges only, Myelomeningocele = meninges + spinal cord.
content.takeAway: Spinal dysraphism is a spectrum of birth defects resulting from failed closure of the spinal neural tube, ranging from the hidden bony defect of spina bifida occulta to the devastating paralysis associated with a myelomeningocele.

content.definition: Satiety and hunger regulation is a complex neurohormonal process, primarily controlled by the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]], which integrates peripheral signals from the gut and adipose tissue to balance energy intake and expenditure.
content.atAGlance:
• Hypothalamic Centers:
    - [[lateral_hypothalamic_nucleus|Lateral Hypothalamus]]: The hunger center. Stimulation induces hunger. A lesion leads to anorexia. Mnemonic: A lesion to the Lateral nucleus makes you Lean.
    - [[d662ec5d|Ventromedial Hypothalamus]]: The satiety center. Stimulation induces satiety. A lesion leads to hyperphagia and obesity. Mnemonic: A lesion to the VentroMedial nucleus makes you Very Massive.
  • Key Hormones:
    - Leptin: A satiety hormone released from adipose tissue. It acts on the hypothalamus to suppress appetite.
    - [[a2cba303|Ghrelin]]: A hunger hormone released from the stomach. It acts on the hypothalamus to stimulate appetite.
    - Insulin: Acts as a satiety signal in the CNS.
    - PYY, CCK: Gut hormones that act as short-term satiety signals.
  • USMLE Tip: Know the roles of the lateral and ventromedial hypothalamus and the primary functions of leptin (satiety) and ghrelin (hunger).
content.takeAway: The regulation of hunger and satiety is a delicate balance orchestrated by the hypothalamus, which weighs the 'eat now' signal from ghrelin against the 'stop eating' signals from leptin and other gut hormones to maintain energy homeostasis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Leptin] --> B(Ventromedial Hypothalamus); B --> C(Satiety); D[Ghrelin] --> E(Lateral Hypothalamus); E --> F(Hunger);

content.definition: Schizophrenia is a chronic, severe mental disorder that affects how a person thinks, feels, and behaves. It is characterized by a breakdown in the relation between thought, emotion, and behavior, leading to faulty perception, inappropriate actions and feelings, and withdrawal from reality into fantasy and delusion.
content.atAGlance:
• Neurotransmitter Changes: The primary hypothesis involves excessive dopaminergic activity in the brain. Specifically, the mesolimbic pathway is thought to be hyperactive (causing positive symptoms), while the mesocortical pathway is thought to be hypoactive (causing negative and cognitive symptoms).
  • Symptoms:
    - Positive Symptoms: Hallucinations (especially auditory), delusions, disorganized speech and behavior.
    - Negative Symptoms: Flat affect, anhedonia, avolition (apathy), alogia (poverty of speech).
    - Cognitive Symptoms: Impaired executive function, attention, and working memory.
  • Diagnosis: Requires ≥2 characteristic symptoms for at least 1 month, with continuous signs of disturbance for at least 6 months.
  • Treatment: Antipsychotic medications, which primarily act as dopamine D2 receptor antagonists, are the mainstay of treatment.
  • USMLE Tip: The dopamine hypothesis is key. Positive symptoms are due to too much dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway, while negative symptoms are due to too little dopamine in the mesocortical pathway.
content.takeAway: Schizophrenia is a complex disorder of thought and perception fundamentally linked to dysregulated dopamine signaling, with an excess in the mesolimbic pathway driving psychosis and a deficit in the mesocortical pathway contributing to negative symptoms.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[↑ Dopamine in Mesolimbic Pathway] --> B(Positive Symptoms); C[↓ Dopamine in Mesocortical Pathway] --> D(Negative Symptoms);

content.definition: Schwann cells are the principal glial cells of the peripheral nervous system (PNS). Their main function is to myelinate the axons of peripheral nerves, which is essential for rapid, saltatory conduction of nerve impulses.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Derived from the [[14c6f2a7|neural crest]].
  • Function: Myelinate axons in the PNS. A single Schwann cell myelinates only one segment of a single axon. They also provide support for unmyelinated axons.
  • Regeneration: Schwann cells play a crucial role in the regeneration of damaged peripheral nerves by forming a 'regeneration tube' (band of Büngner) that guides the regrowing axon.
  • Pathology:
    - [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]]: An autoimmune attack on Schwann cells and their myelin.
    - [[c3f13d85|Charcot-Marie-Tooth Disease]]: A group of hereditary neuropathies often involving mutations in genes related to Schwann cell/myelin function.
    - [[03ecb69e|Schwannoma]]: A benign tumor of Schwann cells.
  • Comparison to Oligodendrocytes: [[a24f9747|Oligodendrocytes]] myelinate axons in the CNS. One oligodendrocyte can myelinate multiple axons, and they do not effectively support regeneration.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the 'one-to-one' rule for Schwann cells: one cell per axon segment. This is a key difference from oligodendrocytes.
content.takeAway: Schwann cells are the dedicated myelinators of the peripheral nervous system, wrapping individual axon segments to ensure fast nerve conduction and, crucially, providing the supportive scaffold necessary for nerve regeneration after injury.

content.definition: A schwannoma is a benign, encapsulated tumor that arises from [[c65a8909|Schwann cells]], the myelin-forming cells of the peripheral nervous system. The most common type is the [[11946667|vestibular schwannoma]] (acoustic neuroma).
content.atAGlance:
• Cell of Origin: Arises from [[c65a8909|Schwann cells]]. The tumor cells are S-100 positive on immunohistochemistry.
  • Location: Can occur on any peripheral or cranial nerve (except CN I and II, which are myelinated by oligodendrocytes). Most commonly affects the vestibular branch of CN VIII at the cerebellopontine angle.
  • Histology: Characterized by a biphasic pattern:
    - Antoni A: Dense, hypercellular areas with spindle cells arranged in palisading patterns (Verocay bodies).
    - Antoni B: Hypocellular, myxoid areas.
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF-2): The presence of bilateral vestibular schwannomas is pathognomonic for NF-2, an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the NF2 gene.
  • USMLE Tip: A tumor at the cerebellopontine angle that is S-100 positive is a schwannoma. If bilateral, the diagnosis is NF-2.
content.takeAway: A schwannoma is a benign tumor of Schwann cells, most famously occurring as a vestibular schwannoma at the cerebellopontine angle, and is histologically identified by its biphasic Antoni A and B patterns and S-100 positivity.

content.definition: A seizure is a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. [[64c08e92|Epilepsy]] is a disease characterized by a predisposition to recurrent, unprovoked seizures.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases: A seizure may have an ictal phase (the event itself) and a postictal phase (a period of confusion or drowsiness after the seizure). An aura may precede the seizure.
  • Classification:
    - [[953ad620|Focal Seizures]]: Originate in one hemisphere. Can be aware or have impaired awareness.
    - [[2e7554b7|Generalized Seizures]]: Involve both hemispheres from the outset. Include tonic-clonic, absence, myoclonic, and atonic types.
  • [[12108f05|Febrile Seizures]]: Common in children aged 6 months to 5 years, triggered by fever. Simple febrile seizures are benign and do not constitute epilepsy.
  • Status Epilepticus: A seizure lasting >5 minutes or recurrent seizures without recovery in between. This is a medical emergency. First-line treatment is IV [[14464617|benzodiazepines]].
  • Withdrawal: Abrupt cessation of CNS depressants, particularly alcohol and [[14464617|benzodiazepines]], is a common cause of provoked seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: The clinical description of the seizure is key to its classification, which in turn guides the choice of anticonvulsant medication.
content.takeAway: A seizure is a 'short circuit' in the brain's electrical activity, and its classification into focal or generalized types based on its origin and spread is the cornerstone of diagnosis and treatment.

content.definition: Selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR) is a neurosurgical procedure used to reduce spasticity in the lower limbs, most commonly in children with spastic diplegic [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]].
content.atAGlance:
• Goal: To permanently reduce muscle spasticity and improve gait and motor function.
  • Procedure: Involves surgically identifying and sectioning (cutting) a portion of the dorsal (sensory) nerve roots in the lumbosacral spine.
  • Mechanism: Spasticity is caused by a hyperexcitable stretch reflex arc. By cutting the sensory nerve rootlets that are firing abnormally, the procedure interrupts the afferent limb of the reflex arc, thereby reducing the spastic motor response.
  • Patient Selection: Typically performed in children with spastic diplegic [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]] who have good underlying muscle strength but whose function is limited by spasticity.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the rationale for SDR: it targets the sensory (afferent) side of the spinal reflex arc to reduce the motor (efferent) output that causes spasticity.
content.takeAway: Selective dorsal rhizotomy is a neurosurgical procedure that alleviates spasticity by selectively cutting the sensory nerve rootlets that are sending abnormal signals, effectively turning down the 'volume' on the hyperactive stretch reflexes that cause muscle stiffness.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Stretched Muscle] --> B(Sensory Afferent - Dorsal Root); B --x C(Selective Dorsal Rhizotomy); C --x D(Spinal Cord); D --x E(Motor Efferent); E --x F(Spastic Contraction);

content.definition: Selegiline is a selective, irreversible inhibitor of monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B). It is used in the treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and, in a transdermal patch formulation, for major depressive disorder.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Selectively and irreversibly inhibits MAO-B, the enzyme that primarily metabolizes [[90adc821|dopamine]] in the brain. This increases the levels of dopamine in the striatum.
  • Clinical Use (Parkinson's): Used as an adjunct to [[541cd176|levodopa/carbidopa]] to help with motor fluctuations ('wearing-off' phenomenon) by prolonging the effect of dopamine. It can also be used as monotherapy in early disease.
  • Selectivity: At standard doses, it is selective for MAO-B over MAO-A (which metabolizes serotonin and norepinephrine). This reduces the risk of hypertensive crisis ('cheese effect') compared to non-selective MAOIs. However, at high doses, it can lose its selectivity.
  • Adverse Effects: Insomnia (as it can be metabolized to amphetamine-like substances), confusion, and hallucinations. Risk of serotonin syndrome if combined with serotonergic drugs.
  • USMLE Tip: Selegiline and rasagiline are the two main MAO-B inhibitors for Parkinson's. Their mechanism is to prevent the breakdown of dopamine in the brain.
content.takeAway: Selegiline helps in Parkinson's disease by selectively blocking MAO-B, the enzyme that degrades dopamine in the brain, thereby preserving the limited dopamine supply and extending the effectiveness of levodopa therapy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dopamine] --MAO-B--> B(DOPAC - Inactive); C[Selegiline] --x B;

content.definition: Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is a type of hearing impairment that results from damage to the inner ear (cochlea) or to the nerve pathways from the inner ear to the brain (vestibulocochlear nerve, CN VIII).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by damage to the sensory hair cells in the cochlea or to the auditory nerve itself. This impairs the transduction of sound vibrations into neural signals or the transmission of those signals to the brain.
  • Common Causes:
    - [[presbycusis|Presbycusis]]: Age-related hearing loss (most common cause).
