    - Noise-induced hearing loss: Damage to hair cells from excessive noise exposure.
    - Ototoxic drugs: Aminoglycosides, loop diuretics, cisplatin.
    - [[11946667|Vestibular schwannoma]]: Tumor compressing CN VIII.
    - Congenital infections: e.g., CMV.
  • Tuning Fork Tests:
    - Rinne Test: Normal. Air conduction (AC) is greater than bone conduction (BC) in both ears, but hearing is diminished overall in the affected ear.
    - Weber Test: Sound lateralizes to the unaffected (good) ear, because the damaged nerve cannot transmit the sound signal.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the tuning fork results: In SNHL, the Weber test lateralizes to the good ear, and the Rinne test is normal (AC > BC).
content.takeAway: Sensorineural hearing loss is a 'wiring problem' of the ear, where damage to the delicate hair cells of the cochlea or the auditory nerve prevents sound from being properly converted into or transmitted as a neural signal, in contrast to the 'plumbing problem' of conductive hearing loss.

content.definition: The primary somatosensory cortex (S1) is the main cortical area for processing tactile information from the body. It is located in the postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Postcentral gyrus of the parietal lobe (Brodmann areas 1, 2, and 3).
  • Function: Receives and processes sensory information from the contralateral side of the body, including touch, pressure, pain, temperature, vibration, and proprioception.
  • Input: Receives its primary input from the ventral posterior nucleus (VPN) of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], which is composed of the [[2ae957b8|VPL]] (for the body) and [[23ac314a|VPM]] (for the face) nuclei.
  • Somatotopic Organization (Sensory Homunculus): The cortex is organized somatotopically, with different body parts represented in specific areas. The face and hands have a disproportionately large representation due to their high sensory acuity.
  • Stroke Effects: A lesion in the primary somatosensory cortex causes contralateral sensory loss (e.g., numbness, paresthesias).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the location (postcentral gyrus) and the somatotopic representation (homunculus), with the leg represented medially (supplied by ACA) and the arm/face represented laterally (supplied by MCA).
content.takeAway: The somatosensory cortex is the brain's primary 'touch map,' a highly organized region in the parietal lobe that receives all tactile information from the thalamus and translates it into our conscious perception of sensation from the contralateral body.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Thalamus - VPL/VPM] --> B(Primary Somatosensory Cortex); B --> C(Conscious Perception of Sensation);

content.definition: Sensory loss is a deficit in one or more of the sensory modalities (e.g., touch, pain, temperature, vibration, proprioception). The pattern of sensory loss is a critical clue for localizing lesions within the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Peripheral Neuropathy: Typically causes a 'glove and stocking' pattern of sensory loss, affecting the distal extremities first.
  • Radiculopathy: Sensory loss in a dermatomal pattern.
  • Spinal Cord Lesions:
    - [[4792bc68|Brown-Séquard Syndrome]]: Ipsilateral loss of proprioception/vibration and contralateral loss of pain/temperature below the lesion.
    - [[d2b8e10c|Syringomyelia]]: 'Cape-like' bilateral loss of pain/temperature in the upper extremities.
  • Brainstem Lesions: Often cause 'crossed' sensory loss (e.g., ipsilateral face, contralateral body), as seen in lateral medullary or pontine syndromes.
  • Thalamic Lesions: Cause contralateral sensory loss of all modalities in the face, arm, and leg.
  • Cortical Lesions: Cause contralateral sensory loss, often with deficits in discriminative sensation (e.g., graphesthesia, stereognosis). Stroke effects depend on the vascular territory.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiating between a dorsal column pattern (loss of vibration/proprioception) and a spinothalamic pattern (loss of pain/temperature) is fundamental to localizing CNS lesions.
content.takeAway: The specific pattern of sensory loss—whether it follows a dermatome, a 'glove and stocking' distribution, or a dissociated pattern in the spinal cord—provides a precise roadmap for pinpointing the location of a neurological lesion.

content.definition: Sensory pathways (or ascending tracts) are neural pathways in the spinal cord and brainstem that transmit somatosensory information from the periphery to the cerebral cortex for conscious perception. The two main pathways are the dorsal column-medial lemniscus system and the spinothalamic tract.
content.atAGlance:
• Dorsal Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway: Transmits fine touch, vibration, and proprioception. It ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal columns and decussates in the medulla.
  • Spinothalamic Tract (Anterolateral System): Transmits pain, temperature, and crude touch. It decussates at the level of the spinal cord and ascends contralaterally.
  • Thalamic Relay: Both major pathways synapse in the ventral posterior nucleus (VPL/VPM) of the thalamus before projecting to the somatosensory cortex.
  • Clinical Application: The different decussation points of these two pathways are the basis for the dissociated sensory loss seen in spinal cord syndromes like Brown-Séquard.
  • USMLE Tip: Master the functions and decussation points of the two main sensory pathways. Dorsal columns = fine touch/proprioception, crosses in medulla. Spinothalamic = pain/temp, crosses in spinal cord.
content.takeAway: The body's sensory information travels to the brain on two main, segregated highways: the dorsal column pathway for fine, discriminative sensations and the spinothalamic pathway for crude, vital sensations like pain and temperature, with their different crossing points being key to neurological diagnosis.

content.definition: Sensory receptors are specialized neurons or cells that transduce sensory stimuli (e.g., touch, temperature, light) into electrical signals (action potentials) that can be interpreted by the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanoreceptors (Touch, Pressure, Vibration):
    - [[1e7ec644|Free Nerve Endings]]: Pain, temperature, crude touch.
    - Meissner's Corpuscles: Fine/light touch, low-frequency vibration. Rapidly adapting.
    - Pacinian Corpuscles: Deep pressure, high-frequency vibration. Rapidly adapting.
    - Merkel's Discs: Deep static touch (shapes, edges), pressure. Slowly adapting.
    - Ruffini Corpuscles: Stretch, slippage of objects. Slowly adapting.
  • Proprioceptors: Muscle spindles (muscle stretch) and Golgi tendon organs (muscle tension).
  • Thermoreceptors: [[1e7ec644|Free nerve endings]] that detect temperature.
  • Nociceptors: [[1e7ec644|Free nerve endings]] that detect pain.
  • Fiber Types: Different receptors are associated with different nerve fiber types, which determines the speed of conduction (e.g., large, myelinated Aβ fibers for fine touch vs. small, unmyelinated C fibers for slow pain).
  • USMLE Tip: Know which receptors are rapidly adapting (Meissner, Pacinian - sense changes) versus slowly adapting (Merkel, Ruffini - sense sustained stimuli).
content.takeAway: Sensory receptors are the body's diverse array of biological transducers, each exquisitely tuned to a specific type of physical or chemical energy, converting the stimuli of the outside world into the electrical language of the nervous system.

content.definition: Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) is a monoamine neurotransmitter that plays a wide-ranging role in modulating mood, sleep, appetite, and cognition. Its dysregulation is implicated in numerous psychiatric disorders.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan. The majority of the body's serotonin is produced in the gut, but in the CNS, it is produced in the raphe nuclei of the brainstem.
  • Function: Involved in the regulation of mood, sleep, anxiety, appetite, and libido.
  • Pathology: A deficiency of serotonin is implicated in [[9a0f5ba6|depression]] and [[d1c786e9|anxiety disorders]].
  • Pharmacology: The serotonin system is a major target for psychotropic drugs.
    - SSRIs (e.g., fluoxetine): Block the reuptake of serotonin, increasing its synaptic levels. First-line for depression and anxiety.
    - [[8c2c618d|SNRIs]]: Block reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine.
    - TCAs: Also block serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake.
    - MAOIs: Inhibit the breakdown of serotonin.
  • Serotonin Syndrome: A potentially life-threatening condition caused by excessive serotonergic activity (e.g., from combining serotonergic drugs). Presents with a triad of autonomic hyperactivity, altered mental status, and neuromuscular abnormalities (clonus, hyperreflexia).
  • Vomiting Center Input: 5-HT3 receptors in the [[93f70f8e|chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)]] and GI tract are involved in the vomiting reflex. 5-HT3 antagonists (e.g., ondansetron) are potent antiemetics.
content.takeAway: Serotonin is a key neuromodulator for mood and well-being, with its deficiency being a central hypothesis for depression, making the enhancement of serotonergic transmission the primary mechanism of action for the most widely prescribed antidepressants.

content.definition: Sevoflurane is a sweet-smelling, non-flammable, halogenated ether used as a volatile inhaled general anesthetic for the induction and maintenance of anesthesia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought to enhance the activity of inhibitory neurotransmitter receptors (like GABAA) and inhibit excitatory receptors (like NMDA).
  • Pharmacokinetics: It has a low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.65), which means it has low solubility in blood. This results in a rapid onset of anesthesia and a rapid recovery upon discontinuation.
  • Clinical Use: It is one of the most commonly used volatile anesthetics, especially in pediatrics, because its non-pungent nature makes it suitable for inhalation induction.
  • Adverse Effects: Causes dose-dependent respiratory depression and myocardial depression (hypotension). It can trigger malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals. It can be nephrotoxic at low fresh gas flow rates due to the formation of Compound A, but this is rarely clinically significant.
  • USMLE Tip: Sevoflurane is known for its rapid induction and recovery and its suitability for inhalation induction, especially in children. Contrast its rapid kinetics with older agents like halothane, which had high blood solubility and thus slow induction.
content.takeAway: Sevoflurane is a modern, widely used inhaled anesthetic favored for its rapid and smooth induction, particularly in children, a property directly related to its low solubility in blood.

content.definition: Skeletal muscle relaxants are a group of drugs used to alleviate symptoms associated with muscle spasticity or acute muscle spasms by acting either on the central nervous system or directly on the muscle.
content.atAGlance:
• Baclofen: A GABAB receptor agonist that acts on the spinal cord to suppress hyperactive reflexes. Used for spasticity in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] and spinal cord injury.
  • Cyclobenzaprine: A centrally acting muscle relaxant, structurally related to TCAs. Used for acute muscle spasms from musculoskeletal conditions. Has significant anticholinergic side effects and causes sedation.
  • Tizanidine: A centrally acting α2-adrenergic agonist that inhibits motor neuron activity. Used for spasticity.
  • Dantrolene: Acts directly on skeletal muscle by blocking Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (inhibits ryanodine receptor). Used to treat malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate the uses: [[1ddc3f08|baclofen]] and tizanidine for chronic spasticity (MS, spinal cord injury), cyclobenzaprine for acute muscle strain, and [[d67a204d|dantrolene]] for life-threatening hyperthermic syndromes.
content.takeAway: Skeletal muscle relaxants reduce muscle hyperactivity through diverse mechanisms, ranging from central GABAergic and adrenergic modulation (baclofen, tizanidine) to direct interference with muscle contraction machinery (dantrolene), the latter being crucial for treating hyperthermic emergencies.

content.definition: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. It is a malignant tumor arising from the immature cells of the retina, caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Caused by two inactivating mutations ('two hits') in the RB1 gene on chromosome 13. It can be sporadic (two acquired somatic mutations in one retinal cell) or hereditary (one inherited germline mutation and one acquired somatic mutation).
  • Hereditary Form: Patients with the hereditary form (autosomal dominant inheritance pattern) are at high risk for bilateral retinoblastoma and have a significantly increased risk of developing secondary malignancies, most notably osteosarcoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: The most common presenting sign is leukocoria (a white pupillary reflex, 'cat's eye reflex') instead of the normal red reflex. [[cdcda821|Strabismus]] (eye misalignment) is the second most common sign.
  • Histology: Characterized by small, round, blue cells forming Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.
  • USMLE Tip: Leukocoria in a child is retinoblastoma until proven otherwise. Remember the 'two-hit' hypothesis of tumor suppressor genes, for which retinoblastoma is the classic example.
content.takeAway: Retinoblastoma is a pediatric eye cancer driven by the inactivation of the RB1 tumor suppressor gene, which classically presents as a 'white pupil' (leukocoria) and, in its hereditary form, carries a lifelong risk of secondary cancers like osteosarcoma.

content.definition: Retinopathy is a general term for any non-inflammatory disease of the retina. It is most often used to describe damage to the retinal blood vessels, which can lead to vision impairment or blindness.
content.atAGlance:
• [[73b00ab0|Diabetic Retinopathy]]: A microvascular complication of diabetes. Can be nonproliferative (microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates) or proliferative (neovascularization).
  • [[549b012e|Hypertensive Retinopathy]]: Retinal vascular damage from chronic hypertension. Signs include arteriolar narrowing, AV nicking, cotton-wool spots, and hemorrhages.
  • [[06a2b849|Retinopathy of Prematurity]]: Abnormal blood vessel development in the retina of premature infants.
  • Retinal Vein/Artery Occlusion: Blockage of retinal vessels leading to ischemia or hemorrhage. [[b69e35b5|CRVO]] has a 'blood and thunder' appearance. [[3334840f|CRAO]] has a 'cherry-red spot'.
  • Retinitis: This term implies inflammation of the retina (e.g., CMV retinitis), and is distinct from the non-inflammatory vasculopathies typically referred to as 'retinopathy'.
  • USMLE Tip: The funduscopic exam is key to differentiating the types of retinopathy. Be able to recognize the classic findings for diabetic, hypertensive, and vascular occlusive retinopathies.
content.takeAway: Retinopathy is a broad term for retinal disease, most commonly referring to the vascular damage caused by systemic conditions like diabetes and hypertension, which manifest with characteristic and diagnostic findings on funduscopic examination.

content.definition: Retinopathy of Prematurity (ROP) is a potentially blinding eye disorder that primarily affects premature infants. It is caused by abnormal development of retinal blood vessels, leading to neovascularization and potential retinal detachment.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology (Two Phases):
    1. Phase 1 (Hyperoxic): Premature birth exposes the immature retina to a relatively hyperoxic environment compared to the uterus. Supplemental oxygen therapy further increases this. High oxygen levels suppress VEGF, causing a cessation of normal retinal vessel growth.
    2. Phase 2 (Hypoxic): As the avascular peripheral retina develops and becomes metabolically active, it becomes hypoxic. This triggers a massive, unregulated overproduction of VEGF, leading to neovascularization.
  • Risk Factors: The primary risk factors are prematurity (low gestational age) and low birth weight. The use of supplemental oxygen is a major contributing factor.
  • Complications: The new, abnormal vessels are fragile and can bleed. They can also form fibrous scar tissue that pulls on the retina, leading to tractional retinal detachment and blindness.
  • Screening & Treatment: All high-risk premature infants undergo regular screening eye exams. Treatment for severe ROP includes laser photocoagulation or anti-VEGF injections to ablate the avascular retina and reduce the stimulus for neovascularization.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the biphasic oxygen-dependent pathophysiology: initial hyperoxia stops normal vessel growth, and subsequent hypoxia drives abnormal vessel growth.
content.takeAway: Retinopathy of Prematurity is a disease of vascular dysregulation, where the premature retina's normal, orderly vessel growth is disrupted by the oxygen-rich extrauterine environment, leading to a delayed, chaotic neovascularization that can detach the retina and cause blindness.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Premature Birth + O2 Therapy] --> B(Phase 1: Hyperoxia); B --> C(↓ VEGF -> Cessation of normal vessel growth); C --> D(Avascular Peripheral Retina); D --> E(Phase 2: Hypoxia); E --> F(↑↑ VEGF); F --> G(Neovascularization); G --> H(Retinal Detachment);

content.definition: A rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is the most common type of retinal detachment, occurring when a tear or break in the retina allows liquefied vitreous humor to seep into the subretinal space, separating the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE).
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: The process is initiated by a full-thickness retinal tear. This is often preceded by a posterior vitreous detachment (PVD), where the aging vitreous gel shrinks and pulls away from the retina, sometimes tearing it in the process.
  • Risk Factors: Myopia (nearsightedness), older age, previous cataract surgery, and eye trauma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients often report a sudden onset of photopsia (flashes of light) and a shower of floaters (corresponding to the PVD and retinal tear). This is followed by a progressive, painless peripheral visual field loss, often described as a "curtain" or shadow moving across the vision.
  • Diagnosis: Fundoscopic examination reveals a detached, gray, undulating retina. The retinal tear may also be visible.
  • Treatment: This is a surgical emergency to prevent permanent vision loss.
  • USMLE Tip: Flashes, floaters, and a curtain-like vision loss are the classic triad for a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
content.takeAway: A rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is a mechanical separation of the retina caused by a tear, which allows vitreous fluid to get underneath and lift the retina off its underlying blood supply, a process heralded by the classic symptoms of flashes and floaters.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Posterior Vitreous Detachment] --> B(Retinal Tear); B --> C(Liquefied Vitreous Enters Subretinal Space); C --> D(Separation of Retina from RPE); D --> E(Retinal Detachment);

content.definition: Riluzole is a neuroprotective drug that is the primary disease-modifying therapy for [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: The exact mechanism is not fully understood, but it is believed to work by decreasing glutamate excitotoxicity. It is thought to inhibit glutamate release and block postsynaptic NMDA and kainate receptors.
  • Clinical Use: Used to treat [[4ed629f9|amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)]]. It has been shown to modestly prolong survival and/or the time to tracheostomy.
  • Efficacy: The benefit is modest, typically extending survival by only a few months. It does not reverse or halt the disease process.
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, dizziness, and elevated liver enzymes (hepatotoxicity), requiring monitoring of LFTs.
  • USMLE Tip: Riluzole is the main drug associated with the treatment of ALS. Remember its proposed mechanism of reducing glutamate excitotoxicity. Mnemonic: Ri-LOU-zole for Lou Gehrig's disease.
content.takeAway: Riluzole is a neuroprotective agent that offers a modest survival benefit in ALS by mitigating glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity, one of the proposed mechanisms of motor neuron death in the disease.

content.definition: Rivastigmine is a reversible [[0835ea01|cholinesterase inhibitor]] used for the symptomatic treatment of mild to moderate [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and dementia associated with [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Reversibly inhibits both acetylcholinesterase (AChE) and butyrylcholinesterase, leading to increased levels of [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] in the brain.
  • Rationale for Use: [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] is associated with a significant loss of cholinergic neurons. Rivastigmine aims to enhance the function of the remaining neurons.
  • Clinical Use: Provides modest, symptomatic improvement in cognitive function in some patients with mild to moderate dementia. It does not alter the course of the underlying disease.
  • Administration: Available as an oral capsule and a transdermal patch. The patch formulation may have better gastrointestinal tolerability.
  • Adverse Effects: Primarily cholinergic side effects, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and dizziness.
  • USMLE Tip: Along with [[47d0372e|donepezil]] and galantamine, rivastigmine is a first-line symptomatic treatment for Alzheimer's, based on the cholinergic hypothesis of the disease.
content.takeAway: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that helps manage the cognitive symptoms of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's dementia by boosting acetylcholine levels, available in both oral and transdermal forms to improve tolerability.

content.definition: Rocuronium is an intermediate-acting, non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent of the aminosteroid class. It is widely used to provide skeletal muscle relaxation for endotracheal intubation and surgery.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] from binding and causing muscle contraction.
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a rapid onset of action, making it a common alternative to succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation when succinylcholine is contraindicated.
  • Metabolism: Primarily eliminated unchanged by the liver (biliary excretion). Its duration can be prolonged in patients with hepatic failure.
  • Adverse Effects: Generally hemodynamically stable with minimal histamine release.
  • Reversal: The blockade can be reversed by [[0835ea01|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., neostigmine) or, more rapidly and completely, by sugammadex, a specific binding agent for rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • USMLE Tip: Rocuronium is a popular non-depolarizing blocker because of its rapid onset. Know that its reversal can be achieved with either traditional cholinesterase inhibitors or the specific reversal agent, sugammadex.
content.takeAway: Rocuronium is a fast-acting, non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that provides a safe and effective alternative to succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation, with the added advantage of being reversible by the specific agent sugammadex.

content.definition: The Romberg sign is a clinical sign of sensory ataxia, elicited by having a patient stand with their feet together and then close their eyes. A positive sign is a significant worsening of unsteadiness or a loss of balance with eye closure.
content.atAGlance:
• Purpose: The test is used to differentiate sensory ataxia from cerebellar ataxia.
  • Physiology of Balance: Balance is maintained by three sensory inputs: proprioception (position sense), vestibular input, and vision. At least two of these three must be intact.
  • Positive Romberg Sign: A positive sign indicates a deficit in proprioception. The patient is able to compensate for the proprioceptive loss by using visual input. When the eyes are closed, this compensation is removed, and the unsteadiness becomes apparent.
  • Associated Conditions: A positive Romberg sign points to a lesion in the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]] of the spinal cord or in the peripheral nerves. It is a classic finding in [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] (neurosyphilis) and [[6f5bea90|subacute combined degeneration]] (B12 deficiency).
  • Negative Romberg Sign: If a patient is unsteady with their eyes open and this does not significantly worsen with eye closure, the ataxia is likely cerebellar in origin.
  • USMLE Tip: A positive Romberg test is a test of proprioception, not cerebellar function.
content.takeAway: The Romberg sign is a simple yet elegant test that unmasks a deficit in proprioception by removing the visual compensation the patient relies on to maintain balance, thereby pointing to a lesion in the dorsal columns or peripheral nerves.

content.definition: The rooting reflex is a primitive reflex present in newborns that helps them find the breast or bottle to begin feeding. It is elicited by stroking the corner of the infant's mouth or cheek.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: Gently stroke the infant's cheek near the corner of the mouth.
  • Normal Response: The infant will turn their head toward the side of the stimulus and open their mouth in an attempt to suck.
  • Timeline: Present at birth and typically disappears by 4 months of age as it becomes a voluntary action.
  • Clinical Significance: It is one of several primitive reflexes tested in the newborn neurological exam to assess brainstem function and development. Its absence may indicate CNS depression or injury.
  • Re-emergence: The reappearance of the rooting reflex in an adult is an abnormal finding known as a frontal release sign, indicating damage to the [[0405ada3|frontal lobe]].
  • USMLE Tip: The rooting reflex is a normal, adaptive reflex in a newborn. Its persistence beyond infancy or its re-emergence in an adult is pathological.
content.takeAway: The rooting reflex is an innate, automatic head-turning and mouth-opening response in infants that facilitates breastfeeding, which is normally suppressed by the maturing frontal lobes after a few months of life.

content.definition: Ropinirole is a non-ergot dopamine agonist used for the treatment of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] and restless legs syndrome.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Directly stimulates dopamine D2 and D3 receptors in the brain, mimicking the effect of dopamine.
  • Class: Non-ergot dopamine agonist, along with pramipexole. These are preferred over older ergot derivatives like [[d24a5ff0|bromocriptine]] due to a better side effect profile.
  • Clinical Use (Parkinson's): Used as monotherapy in younger patients to delay the need for levodopa, or as an adjunct to levodopa in older patients to reduce motor fluctuations ('off' time).
  • Clinical Use (Other): A first-line treatment for moderate to severe [[919caff2|restless legs syndrome]].
  • Adverse Effects: Nausea, postural hypotension, somnolence (including sudden-onset 'sleep attacks'), and hallucinations. A notable side effect is impulse control disorders (e.g., pathological gambling, compulsive shopping).
  • USMLE Tip: Ropinirole and pramipexole are the main non-ergot dopamine agonists. Remember their use in both Parkinson's and restless legs syndrome, and be aware of the unique side effect of impulse control disorders.
content.takeAway: Ropinirole is a non-ergot dopamine agonist that directly stimulates dopamine receptors to compensate for the deficiency in Parkinson's disease, but its use can be complicated by CNS side effects, including the unusual development of impulse control disorders.

content.definition: Ropivacaine is a long-acting, amide-type local anesthetic. It is structurally similar to [[181a22b1|bupivacaine]] but is associated with a lower risk of cardiotoxicity.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism of Action: Blocks voltage-gated Na+ channels in nerve membranes, preventing the generation and conduction of nerve impulses.
  • Class: Amide local anesthetic (has two 'i's in its name).
  • Pharmacokinetics: Has a long duration of action.
  • Clinical Use: Used for regional anesthesia, including epidural, spinal, and peripheral nerve blocks for surgery and postoperative pain control.
  • Advantage over Bupivacaine: It is less cardiotoxic than [[181a22b1|bupivacaine]], making it a safer choice, especially for techniques that carry a higher risk of systemic absorption. It also produces a greater degree of motor block relative to sensory block ('motor-sensory separation').
  • USMLE Tip: Ropivacaine is the 'safer bupivacaine.' It offers a similar long duration of action with a reduced risk of life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias.
content.takeAway: Ropivacaine is a long-acting amide local anesthetic that provides effective regional anesthesia with a better cardiovascular safety profile than its predecessor, bupivacaine.

content.definition: Rosenthal fibers are thick, elongated, eosinophilic (pink), corkscrew-shaped protein aggregates found in the cytoplasm of astrocytes. They are a characteristic histological finding in certain slow-growing glial processes and tumors.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: On H&E stain, they appear as bright pink, irregular, rope-like or 'corkscrew' inclusions within astrocytic processes.
  • Composition: Composed of aggregates of intermediate filament proteins, including glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP), along with heat shock proteins.
  • Classic Association: They are the histological hallmark of a pilocytic astrocytoma, the most common primary brain tumor in children.
  • Other Conditions: Can also be seen in areas of long-standing gliosis and in Alexander disease, a rare leukodystrophy.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of Rosenthal fibers in a biopsy of a pediatric cerebellar cystic tumor is diagnostic for pilocytic astrocytoma.
content.takeAway: Rosenthal fibers are distinctive eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped inclusions that are the microscopic signature of a pilocytic astrocytoma, representing aggregates of glial proteins within the tumor cells.

content.definition: Ruffini corpuscles (or Ruffini endings) are slowly adapting mechanoreceptors found in the skin and joint capsules that are sensitive to sustained pressure and skin stretch.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Spindle-shaped, encapsulated receptors located in the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Function: They respond to sustained pressure and skin stretch. They are also thought to contribute to the perception of warmth.
  • Adaptation: They are slowly adapting, meaning they continue to fire action potentials as long as the stimulus is present. This allows for the perception of constant stimuli.
  • Clinical Significance: They contribute to our ability to perceive the shape of objects held in the hand and to sense finger position and movement.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate slowly adapting receptors (Ruffini, Merkel) from rapidly adapting receptors (Pacinian, Meissner). Slowly adapting receptors are good for sensing static properties like pressure and shape, while rapidly adapting receptors are good for sensing dynamic properties like vibration and texture changes.
content.takeAway: Ruffini corpuscles are the skin's stretch detectors, slowly adapting mechanoreceptors that provide continuous information about sustained pressure and the distortion of the skin, crucial for proprioception and grip control.

content.definition: Saccular aneurysms, also known as berry aneurysms, are thin-walled, sac-like outpouchings of a cerebral artery, typically located at arterial branch points within the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]]. Their rupture is the most common cause of non-traumatic [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Most commonly found at the junction of the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery (AComA)]] with the anterior cerebral artery. The second most common site is the junction of the posterior communicating artery (PComA) with the internal carotid artery.
  • Pathophysiology: Believed to form due to a congenital weakness in the vessel wall at arterial bifurcations, which is exacerbated over time by hemodynamic stress from hypertension.
  • Associated Conditions: Increased incidence in patients with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and Marfan syndrome.
  • Presentation: Usually asymptomatic until rupture. Rupture causes a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]], presenting with a sudden, explosive "worst headache of my life." A large, unruptured aneurysm can cause symptoms by compressing adjacent structures (e.g., a PComA aneurysm compressing CN III).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with ADPKD who develops a sudden, severe headache should be immediately evaluated for a ruptured saccular aneurysm.
content.takeAway: Saccular aneurysms are silent vascular time bombs located at the branch points of the Circle of Willis; their rupture leads to a devastating subarachnoid hemorrhage, classically presenting as a 'thunderclap headache'.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Arterial Bifurcation in Circle of Willis] --> B(Congenital Wall Weakness); B --Hypertension--> C(Saccular Aneurysm Formation); C --> D{Rupture}; D --> E[Subarachnoid Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Satellite cells are a type of glial cell found in the peripheral nervous system (PNS). They form a thin sheath around the cell bodies of neurons located in the peripheral ganglia (e.g., dorsal root ganglia, autonomic ganglia).
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Derived from the [[14c6f2a7|neural crest]].
  • Location: Surround neuronal cell bodies within PNS ganglia.
  • Function: They provide structural support and regulate the chemical microenvironment of the neurons they surround, similar to the role of [[8192f595|astrocytes]] in the CNS. They help control the extracellular environment by absorbing neurotransmitters and supplying nutrients to the neurons.
  • Clinical Relevance: Can be involved in neuropathic pain states and may be affected by viral infections like Herpes Simplex Virus, which establishes latency in sensory ganglia.
  • USMLE Tip: Associate satellite cells with the support of neuronal cell bodies in the PNS, just as astrocytes support neurons in the CNS.
content.takeAway: Satellite cells are the dedicated support cells for neuronal cell bodies in the peripheral nervous system, acting as a protective and homeostatic buffer around the ganglia.

content.definition: Recklinghausen disease is the eponym for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder characterized by the growth of tumors along nerves and the presence of skin and eye findings.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Autosomal dominant mutation in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 17. Mnemonic: 17 letters in 'von Recklinghausen'.
  • Pathophysiology: The NF1 gene encodes neurofibromin, a negative regulator of the RAS signaling pathway. Loss of function leads to uncontrolled cell growth.
  • Clinical Features (Mnemonic CICLOPSS):
    - Café-au-lait spots: Hyperpigmented macules with smooth borders ('coast of California').
    - Intellectual disability (learning disabilities are common).
    - Cutaneous neurofibromas: Benign nerve sheath tumors.
    - Lisch nodules: Pigmented hamartomas in the iris.
    - Optic gliomas.
    - Pheochromocytomas.
    - Seizures / Sphenoid dysplasia.
  • USMLE Tip: The presence of ≥6 café-au-lait spots and cutaneous neurofibromas is highly suggestive of NF-1.
content.takeAway: Recklinghausen disease (NF-1) is a multisystem genetic disorder caused by a faulty tumor suppressor gene, leading to a characteristic constellation of skin findings (café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas), eye findings (Lisch nodules), and an increased risk of various tumors.

content.definition: Reflexes are involuntary and nearly instantaneous movements in response to a stimulus, mediated by a neural pathway called a reflex arc. They are fundamental to the neurological examination for assessing the integrity of the nervous system.
content.atAGlance:
• Spinal (Clinical) Reflexes: Test specific spinal nerve roots.
    - Deep Tendon Reflexes (DTRs): Monosynaptic stretch reflexes (e.g., patellar, Achilles).
    - Superficial Reflexes: Polysynaptic (e.g., cremasteric, anal wink).
  • Cranial Nerve Reflexes: Test brainstem integrity.
    - Pupillary Light Reflex: CN II (afferent), CN III (efferent).
    - Corneal Reflex: CN V1 (afferent), CN VII (efferent).
    - Gag Reflex: CN IX (afferent), CN X (efferent).
  • Primitive Reflexes: Present in infants (e.g., Moro, rooting, Babinski) and disappear as the CNS matures. Their re-emergence in adults indicates frontal lobe damage.
  • Grading of DTRs: A scale from 0 (absent) to 4+ (clonus). 2+ is normal. Hyporeflexia (0, 1+) suggests an LMN lesion. Hyperreflexia (3+, 4+) suggests a UMN lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: The state of the reflexes is a primary tool for differentiating between upper and lower motor neuron lesions.
content.takeAway: The testing of reflexes, from the simple knee-jerk to complex cranial nerve reflexes, provides a direct and objective assessment of the functional integrity of specific pathways throughout the central and peripheral nervous system.

content.definition: Refractive errors are a group of common vision problems that occur when the shape of the eye prevents light from focusing directly on the retina, resulting in blurred vision. They are corrected with eyeglasses, contact lenses, or surgery.
content.atAGlance:
• [[myopia|Myopia]] (Nearsightedness): Light focuses in front of the retina, either because the eyeball is too long or the lens/cornea system is too powerful. Distant objects are blurry. Corrected with a concave (-) lens.
  • [[62a81479|Hyperopia]] (Farsightedness): Light focuses behind the retina, either because the eyeball is too short or the lens/cornea system is too weak. Near objects are blurry. Corrected with a convex (+) lens.
  • [[18cff34e|Astigmatism]]: The cornea or lens has an irregular, non-spherical curvature, causing light to focus at multiple points. Vision is blurred at all distances. Corrected with a cylindrical lens.
  • [[presbyopia|Presbyopia]]: Age-related loss of accommodation, making it difficult to focus on near objects. Caused by stiffening of the lens.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the basic optics: Myopia needs a diverging (concave) lens to move the focal point back. Hyperopia needs a converging (convex) lens to move the focal point forward.
content.takeAway: Refractive errors are a mismatch between the eye's focusing power and its length, leading to blurred vision that is correctable by using lenses to precisely adjust the path of light so it lands perfectly on the retina.

content.definition: A Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, is a clinical sign indicating a decreased response to light in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye relative to the other. It is detected using the swinging flashlight test.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by a unilateral or asymmetric lesion of the afferent visual pathway, anterior to the optic chiasm (i.e., in the retina or optic nerve).
  • Swinging Flashlight Test: A light is swung back and forth between the two eyes. In a normal individual, both pupils will remain constricted. In a patient with an RAPD in the right eye, when the light is swung from the normal left eye to the abnormal right eye, both pupils will paradoxically dilate.
  • Explanation: The affected eye perceives the bright light as if it were dim, so the direct response is weak. When the light swings from the good eye (which caused strong bilateral constriction) to the bad eye, the weaker signal from the bad eye is not enough to maintain the constriction, and both pupils dilate.
  • Classic Cause: The most common cause is a lesion of the optic nerve, such as [[98a63a59|optic neuritis]] (often seen in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]]). Other causes include severe retinal disease or [[3334840f|central retinal artery occlusion]].
  • USMLE Tip: An RAPD is a sign of an afferent pathway problem, not an efferent (CN III) problem. The pupils themselves are capable of constricting; the problem is that the brain isn't receiving a strong enough 'light on' signal from the affected eye.
content.takeAway: A Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect is a subtle but crucial sign of unilateral optic nerve or retinal disease, unmasked by the swinging flashlight test, where the pupils paradoxically dilate when light is shone into the affected eye because the 'light signal' it sends to the brain is weaker than the consensual signal it was just receiving from the healthy eye.

content.definition: Rapid Eye Movement (REM) sleep is a unique stage of sleep characterized by random rapid movement of the eyes, accompanied by low muscle tone throughout the body, and the propensity of the sleeper to dream vividly.
content.atAGlance:
• EEG Pattern: EEG shows low-voltage, high-frequency, sawtooth waves, which resembles the EEG of an awake, active brain. This is why it is often called 'paradoxical sleep'.
  • Physiological Changes: Characterized by rapid eye movements, muscle atonia (paralysis of major voluntary muscles), and variable heart rate and respiration. Penile/clitoral tumescence also occurs.
  • Function: Believed to be crucial for memory consolidation, emotional processing, and brain development.
  • Dreaming: The majority of vivid, story-like dreaming occurs during REM sleep.
  • [[63b44bb7|REM Sleep Behavior Disorder]]: A parasomnia where the normal muscle atonia of REM sleep is absent, causing individuals to physically act out their dreams.
  • USMLE Tip: REM sleep increases in duration and frequency in the later part of the night. Alcohol and benzodiazepines are known to suppress REM sleep.
content.takeAway: REM sleep is a paradoxical state where the brain is highly active, as if awake, yet the body is almost completely paralyzed, creating the ideal stage for vivid dreaming without the risk of physical enactment.

content.definition: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia characterized by the loss of normal muscle atonia during REM sleep, leading to the physical enactment of vivid, often violent or action-filled dreams.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Failure of the brainstem mechanisms (particularly in the pons) that normally induce muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients may shout, punch, kick, or jump out of bed during sleep, corresponding to the content of their dreams. This can result in injury to the patient or their bed partner.
  • Classic Association: RBD is a very strong predictor of future neurodegenerative disease, particularly α-synucleinopathies.
  • Associated Diseases: A majority of patients with idiopathic RBD will eventually develop [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]], [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]], or multiple system atrophy, often years or decades after the onset of RBD.
  • USMLE Tip: An older male patient who reports acting out violent dreams and has injured his spouse during sleep should raise immediate suspicion for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder, which should be considered a prodromal sign of Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia.
content.takeAway: REM Sleep Behavior Disorder is more than just a sleep disturbance; it is a critical early warning sign of an underlying α-synucleinopathy, where the failure to paralyze muscles during dreaming precedes the onset of motor and cognitive symptoms of diseases like Parkinson's by many years.

content.definition: Respiratory failure is a condition in which the respiratory system fails in one or both of its gas exchange functions: oxygenation and carbon dioxide elimination. It is classified as hypoxemic or hypercapnic.
content.atAGlance:
• Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure (Type 1): Characterized by low PaO2 with a normal or low PaCO2. Caused by V/Q mismatch or shunting (e.g., pneumonia, ARDS, pulmonary embolism).
  • Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure (Type 2): Characterized by high PaCO2 (with or without hypoxemia). Caused by inadequate alveolar ventilation ('can't breathe') due to decreased respiratory drive, neuromuscular weakness, or increased dead space.
  • Neuromuscular Causes: Several neurological disorders can lead to hypercapnic respiratory failure by weakening the muscles of respiration (diaphragm, intercostals).
    - [[ed52e40b|Guillain-Barré Syndrome]]: Ascending paralysis can involve the diaphragm.
    - [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]]: Progressive weakness of respiratory muscles is the usual cause of death.
    - Myasthenia Gravis: A myasthenic crisis can cause acute respiratory failure.
  • USMLE Tip: In a patient with a known neuromuscular disorder, monitoring respiratory function (e.g., with vital capacity or negative inspiratory force measurements) is critical to anticipate and manage impending respiratory failure.
content.takeAway: Respiratory failure in the context of neurological disease is typically a hypercapnic failure, a 'pump problem' where the muscles of breathing are too weak to adequately ventilate the lungs, leading to a buildup of carbon dioxide.

content.definition: A resting tremor is an involuntary, rhythmic, oscillatory movement that occurs when a body part is relaxed and completely supported against gravity. It is characteristically suppressed or diminished by voluntary movement.
content.atAGlance:
• Description: A tremor that is present at rest. It often has a low frequency (4-6 Hz).
  • Classic Association: The hallmark and often the first symptom of [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]].
  • Parkinsonian Tremor: Typically starts asymmetrically in one hand and has a characteristic "pill-rolling" quality (a circular movement of the thumb and index finger).
  • Pathophysiology: Caused by dysfunction in the [[ed462927|basal ganglia]], specifically the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • Differentiation: It is crucial to differentiate a resting tremor from other types:
    - [[40039e56|Essential Tremor]]: A postural and action tremor that is absent at rest.
    - Intention Tremor: A tremor that worsens on goal-directed movement, indicative of a cerebellar lesion.
  • USMLE Tip: A tremor that is present when the patient's hands are in their lap but disappears when they reach for an object is a resting tremor, and the most likely diagnosis is Parkinson disease.
content.takeAway: A resting tremor is the classic 'pill-rolling' tremor of Parkinson disease, a sign of basal ganglia dysfunction that is uniquely present when the limb is at rest and paradoxically improves with voluntary action.

content.definition: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS), also known as Willis-Ekbom disease, is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the legs, which is typically accompanied by or caused by uncomfortable and unpleasant sensations in the legs.
content.atAGlance:
• Diagnostic Criteria (URGE):
    - Urge to move the legs.
    - Rest worsens the symptoms.
    - Getting up and moving provides relief.
    - Evening and night are when symptoms are worse.
  • Pathophysiology: The exact cause is unknown, but it is strongly linked to iron deficiency in the central nervous system (even with normal peripheral iron stores) and dysfunction of the dopaminergic system.
  • Secondary Causes: Can be secondary to iron deficiency anemia, pregnancy, end-stage renal disease, and [[5bc4bd07|diabetes mellitus]] (peripheral neuropathy).
  • Treatment:
    - First-line: Address any underlying iron deficiency. Lifestyle modifications.
    - Pharmacotherapy: [[c36650bd|Dopamine agonists]] (e.g., pramipexole, [[16a1a322|ropinirole]]) or [[f608d2b0|gabapentinoids]] (gabapentin, pregabalin) are first-line agents.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient complaining of an 'uncomfortable, creepy-crawly' sensation in their legs at night that is only relieved by getting up and walking is the classic presentation of RLS. The first step in workup is to check iron studies (ferritin).
content.takeAway: Restless Legs Syndrome is a sensorimotor disorder driven by CNS iron deficiency and dopaminergic dysfunction, which creates an overwhelming urge to move the legs, particularly during periods of rest in the evening.

content.definition: The Reticular Activating System (RAS) is a diffuse network of neurons located in the brainstem tegmentum that projects widely to the thalamus and cerebral cortex. It plays a crucial role in regulating wakefulness, arousal, and consciousness.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: A network of nuclei within the reticular formation of the brainstem (midbrain, pons, medulla).
  • Function: The RAS is the 'on switch' for the brain. It filters incoming sensory stimuli and projects to the cortex (via the thalamus) to maintain a state of alertness and consciousness.
  • Lesion Effects: Damage to the RAS can lead to a profound reduction in arousal and wakefulness, resulting in [[d36eed18|coma]].
  • Causes of Damage: Lesions can be structural (e.g., brainstem stroke, hemorrhage, tumor, herniation) or metabolic/toxic (e.g., drug overdose, hypoglycemia, hypoxia).
  • USMLE Tip: Consciousness is maintained by either two functioning cerebral hemispheres or one functioning brainstem (specifically the RAS). Therefore, coma can result from either bilateral hemispheric damage or a focal brainstem lesion affecting the RAS.
content.takeAway: The Reticular Activating System is the brain's arousal center, a brainstem network that constantly bombards the cortex with activating signals to maintain consciousness; its failure leads to the profound unconsciousness of coma.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Sensory Input] --> B(Reticular Activating System); B --> C(Thalamus); C --> D(Cerebral Cortex); D --> E(Arousal/Consciousness);

content.definition: Retinal artery occlusion is the blockage of the central retinal artery or one of its branches, leading to acute ischemia of the inner retina and sudden, painless vision loss. It is considered an ocular stroke.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - [[3334840f|Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO)]]: Blockage of the main retinal artery. Causes severe, profound vision loss affecting the entire visual field.
    - Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO): Blockage of a smaller branch. Causes a sectoral visual field defect.
  • Etiology: Most commonly caused by an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque in the ipsilateral carotid artery or from the heart (e.g., atrial fibrillation). Giant cell arteritis is an important cause to consider in the elderly.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden, painless, monocular vision loss.
  • Fundoscopy: Classic findings include a pale, edematous retina and a "cherry-red spot" at the macula in CRAO. In BRAO, the findings are localized to a sector of the retina.
  • USMLE Tip: The 'cherry-red spot' is pathognomonic for CRAO. This is an ophthalmologic emergency requiring immediate evaluation for stroke risk factors.
content.takeAway: A retinal artery occlusion is an ischemic stroke of the eye, where an embolus lodges in the retinal circulation, causing sudden, painless blindness and the classic fundoscopic sign of a cherry-red spot on a pale retina.

content.definition: A retinal detachment is a serious eye condition where the neurosensory retina separates from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), depriving the photoreceptors of their blood supply from the choroid.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - [[f48498a3|Rhegmatogenous]]: Most common. Caused by a full-thickness retinal tear that allows liquefied vitreous to seep underneath the retina.
    - Tractional: Scar tissue (e.g., from proliferative diabetic retinopathy) contracts and pulls the retina off.
    - Exudative: Fluid accumulates under the retina without a tear, due to inflammation or vascular leakage.
  • Clinical Presentation: The classic symptoms are a sudden onset of photopsia (flashes of light), a shower of floaters, and a progressive peripheral visual field defect described as a "curtain" or shadow. This is a painless event.
  • Risk Factors: Myopia, older age, previous cataract surgery, and eye trauma.
  • Management: This is a surgical emergency. The goal is to reattach the retina as soon as possible to prevent permanent vision loss, especially if the macula is still attached.
  • USMLE Tip: The triad of flashes, floaters, and a curtain-like vision loss is the classic presentation of a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.
content.takeAway: A retinal detachment is the separation of the retina from its vital choroidal blood supply, a sight-threatening emergency often heralded by the premonitory symptoms of light flashes and floaters.

content.definition: Retinal disorders are a group of conditions affecting the retina, the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. These disorders can be vascular, degenerative, or inflammatory and are a major cause of vision loss.
content.atAGlance:
• Vascular Retinopathies:
    - [[73b00ab0|Diabetic Retinopathy]]: Microaneurysms, hemorrhages, neovascularization.
    - [[549b012e|Hypertensive Retinopathy]]: AV nicking, cotton-wool spots.
    - [[ae06ecfa|Retinal Artery Occlusion]]: Cherry-red spot.
    - [[0b8cd9eb|Retinal Vein Occlusion]]: 'Blood and thunder' hemorrhages.
  • Degenerative Disorders:
    - [[c63255c8|Age-related Macular Degeneration]]: Drusen, central vision loss.
    - [[f7063b6e|Retinitis Pigmentosa]]: Peripheral vision loss, night blindness, bone spicule pigmentation.
  • Structural Disorders:
    - [[38c092f9|Retinal Detachment]]: Flashes, floaters, 'curtain' of vision loss.
  • Inflammatory Disorders:
    - Retinitis: Inflammation of the retina, often infectious (e.g., CMV retinitis).
  • USMLE Tip: Funduscopic examination is key to diagnosing retinal disorders. Be able to recognize the classic appearance of each of these conditions.
content.takeAway: Retinal disorders are a diverse group of sight-threatening conditions, each with a characteristic funduscopic appearance that reflects the underlying vascular, degenerative, or inflammatory pathology.

content.definition: A retinal vein occlusion is the blockage of the central retinal vein or one of its branches, leading to venous stasis, retinal hemorrhage, and edema.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - [[b69e35b5|Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO)]]: Blockage of the main retinal vein at the optic nerve head. Affects the entire retina.
    - [[0f0fbfa0|Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO)]]: Blockage of a smaller branch, typically at an AV crossing. Affects a quadrant of the retina.
  • Risk Factors: Strongly associated with systemic vascular diseases like hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia.
  • Clinical Presentation: Sudden, painless, unilateral blurring or loss of vision.
  • Fundoscopy: The classic appearance is a "blood and thunder" fundus, with widespread (CRVO) or sectoral (BRVO) retinal hemorrhages, venous dilation, and cotton-wool spots.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from retinal artery occlusion. Vein occlusion = hemorrhagic, 'blood and thunder'. Artery occlusion = ischemic, 'cherry-red spot'.
content.takeAway: A retinal vein occlusion is a vascular 'plumbing backup' in the eye, where a thrombus obstructs venous outflow, causing a dramatic, hemorrhagic retinopathy and vision loss.

content.definition: Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a group of inherited retinal dystrophies characterized by the progressive degeneration of photoreceptor cells (primarily rods) and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), leading to progressive vision loss.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: Genetically heterogeneous, with autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked inheritance patterns described.
  • Pathophysiology: The primary defect is in the rods, leading to their progressive death. Cone degeneration follows later in the disease course.
  • Clinical Presentation: The classic initial symptom is night blindness (nyctalopia) due to rod dysfunction. This is followed by a progressive loss of the peripheral visual field, leading to 'tunnel vision.' Central vision is typically spared until late in the disease.
  • Fundoscopy: The classic triad of findings includes:
    1. Bone spicule-like pigmentation in the mid-periphery of the retina.
    2. Arteriolar attenuation (narrowing of retinal vessels).
    3. Optic disc pallor.
  • Associated Conditions: Can be a feature of systemic syndromes like Usher syndrome (RP and deafness) and abetalipoproteinemia.
  • USMLE Tip: A young patient complaining of difficulty seeing at night and bumping into things in their peripheral vision, with bone spicules on fundoscopy, is the classic presentation of retinitis pigmentosa.
content.takeAway: Retinitis pigmentosa is a hereditary retinal dystrophy that begins with the death of rod photoreceptors, causing an insidious onset of night blindness and a slow constriction of the visual field, leaving the patient with 'tunnel vision' in advanced stages.
